Headline: India DLF: Shares To Debut On Bourses July 5
Story: MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--Shares of India's DLF Ltd., the country's largest real estate developer by number of properties, will debut on stock exchanges July 5, the company's Chief Financial Officer Ramesh Sanka told Dow Jones Newswires Saturday.   The shares will list on the Bombay Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange.   The company priced its 175-million share initial public offering at INR525 per share, the middle level of the indicative price band of INR500-INR550.   The overall issue was subscribed 3.47 times at close on June 14. Subscriptions had opened June 11.   The qualified institutional buyers' portion was subscribed about 5.13 times, the retail portion about one time and the non-institutional investors' portion 1.17 times.   DLF raised $2.25 billion in India's largest IPO to date, pushing the IPO by Cairn India Ltd. (532792.BY), which had raised $1.92 billion in January, to second place.   The flagship company of the DLF Group, DLF is 97.4% owned by its founders, Chairman K.P. Singh and his family.   It develops residential, commercial and retail properties.   After the IPO, the founder group's stake will fall to 87.4%.     -By Romit Guha, Dow Jones Newswires; 91-9900181471; romit.guha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 01:20 ET (05:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) New Debt Woes Produce Good Buyout Bets
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Wall Street's  worries about the financing of giant leveraged buyouts have depressed the shares of takeover targets, creating opportunities for investors willing to bet that the deals will be completed.   Pending LBOs could require up to $300 billion in financing, prompting concern about the willingness of banks and high-yield investors to absorb that mountain of debt. In the face of such uncertainty, investors now can earn 10%-plus returns on such targets as Harrah'sEntertainment (ticker: HET), Alltel (AT), Alliance Data Systems (ADS) and First Data (FDC).   "The market is about as attractive as we've seen in a while," says Mike Shannon, co-manager of the $1.9 billion Merger Fund (MERFX), an arbitrage fund. He says the annualized return on about 150 targets worldwide is about 15%, versus 12% just a week ago.   Merger arbitragers buy shares of companies that have agreed to be taken over. The investor stands to earn a return based on the spread between a company's current share price and the presumed takeover price. Because most takeovers are now leveraged buyouts, merger arbitrage hinges on private-equity firms' getting financing for their deals.   Takeover stocks sold off last week when investors balked at a $3.6 billion debt offering from U.S. Foodservice, being sold by Ahold (AHO), the Dutch supermarket operator. LBO shares later rebounded, following the success of a financing by $7 billion LBO target Dollar General, albeit at higher-than-expected interest rates. Dollar General, whose shares dipped below $21.50 Monday, finished Friday at $21.91, just shy of the $22 price for the deal, due to close this week. Said one arbitrager: "Disaster has been postponed, if not averted."   Harrah's, which has agreed to be bought by Apollo Management and TPG Group for $17 billion, or $90 a share, traded Friday at $85.40. So investors buying Harrah's stand to make $4.60 a share, about a 12% annualized return, assuming the transaction closes around year end.   The best scenario for arbitragers is a bidding war. After Blackstone Group (BX) announced a deal to buy Equity Office Properties last November for $48.50 a share, a group led by Vornado Realty Trust (VNO) sought to top the bid. Ultimately, Blackstone prevailed, offering $55.50 a share. Bidding wars are growing less frequent as LBO financing gets more problematic. Archstone-Smith (ASN), an apartment REIT, is due to be purchased in a $13 billion LBO at $60.75 a share. Its shares have dropped to $59.10 from a June high of $62, as investors figure there will be no topping bid.   One deal with a wide arbitrage spread involves XM Satellite Radio, which has agreed to merge with its only direct competitor, Sirius Satellite Radio. XM trades at $11.70, $2 below the value of Sirius' all-stock offer, because of worries that the accord may blow up on antitrust grounds, sending XM shares tumbling.   Another deal worrying Wall Street involves Tribune, the newspaper and broadcasting company being purchased by real-estate tycoon Sam Zell in an LBO for $13 billion, or $34 a share. A month ago, Tribune bought 126 million of its shares at $34 and plans to purchase the remaining 117 million outstanding at $34 by year end.   Investors' fears about Zell's ability to complete the transaction have sent Tribune down to $29.50 from $33 a month ago. The company now has $9 billion of debt, which will rise to about $13 billion if it completes the leveraged buyout -- a big load given the financial pressures facing Tribune and the newspaper industry. This year's cash flow may not top $1.2 billion, meaning a private Tribune could have debt exceeding 10 times cash flow. Most companies try to keep debt below three times cash flow, and even highly leveraged firms seek to hold the ratio to seven or eight. Underscoring the challenge, Tribune's revenue sank 11% in May.   Craig Huber, a bearish newspaper analyst at Lehman Brothers, has written that, if the Zell buyout fails, Tribune will sink to $4 to $5. He may be overly pessimistic, but his analysis is helping spook investors -- and presenting opportunities.   The LBO business is getting tougher as financing gets scarcer and more expensive. Yet investors willing to play the takeover arbitrage game are being reasonably paid to take the risks.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Thai PTT:Star Petroleum Refining Seen Launching IPO By End-07
Story: PATTAYA (Dow Jones)--Star Petroleum Refining Co., or SPRC, is expected to launch its initial public offering by the end of this year, said Prasert Bunsumpun, president of PTT PCL (PTT.TH), Thailand's oil and gas giant, adding that PTT plans to partially divest its 36% stake in the company.   "We've decided we would divest some stake in SPRC via the share offering," Prasert told reporters late Friday.   Earlier, PTT considered selling its stake to U.S.-based Chevron Corp. (CVX), which currently owns a 64% stake in SPRC, or swap its stake for a share of Chevron's upstream petroleum business overseas.   SPRC is expected toraise THB20 billion from the Stock Exchange of Thailand. Its market capitalization is estimated to be worth THB60 billion, Prasert said.   After the IPO, PTT's ownership in SPRC would decline to 25%, while that of Chevron will be cut to 45%. PTT would further divest its stake in its refinery affiliate afterwards, Prasert said.   Under its agreement with the government, SPRC is required to list on the Stock Exchange of Thailand in an exchange for obtaining a refinery license.   SPRC is operating a 150,000 barrel-per-day refinery in the country's eastern seaboard area.     -By Supunnabul Suwannakij, Dow Jones Newswires; 66 2266 0744; tu.suwannakij@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 04:34 ET (08:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Energy Grid Operator REN Offering 93.1 Times Oversubscribed
Story: LISBON (Dow Jones)--Portuguese energy-grid operator Redes Energeticas Nacionais, or REN, said in a regulatory filing Saturday that its initial public offering is 93.1 times oversubscribed so far.   The subscription period runs June 25 to July 6, with REN shares scheduled to debut July 10.   REN is offering up to 15% of its share capital in an IPO, as part of a broader restructuring of the country's energy sector.   Of this 15%, 10% is being sold by the Portuguese government and 5% by utility Energias de Portugal SA (EDP.LB).   In addition to this public offering, REN is itself placing directly shares representing 9% of its equity.   After the operation, REN will have a free float of 24%.   The Portuguese government approved an indicative price range of EUR2.35-EUR2.75 per share for REN, valuing the company at between EUR1.25 billion and EUR1.47 billion. The final price will be set July 9.     Company website: http://www.ren.pt     -By Filipa Cunha, Dow Jones Newswires; +351-21-3191863; filipa.cunha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 08:06 ET (12:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Fight Apple's Temptations - Briefly
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   It's the software, stupid.   That's what Steve Jobs and Apple fans have been saying for weeks leading up to Friday's frenzied launch of the much-hyped iPhone.   Jobs and his flock argue that Apple's inimitable knack for elegant and easy-to-use software will distinguish the iPhone from hundreds of wireless handsets made by engineering-centric telecom incumbents, such as Nokia (NOK), Motorola (MOT), Sony-Ericsson (SNE and ERIC), Samsung (SSNLF), Research In Motion (RIMM), and others. (See related story on page 16.)   The prelaunch verdict for the iPhone was positive as all four technology critics from the country's three largest newspapers and a major newsweekly gave it a thumbs up, based largely on its software-driven features. But the vote of the masses over the next several weeks is what matters most, and will determine the fate of what Jobs called "the most revolutionary and exciting product in Apple's history."   The true test will be the durability and reliability of the devices as well as consumer acceptance of AT&T's (ticker: T) less-than-3G network. Together they could determine the iPhone's success in the cut-throat world of wireless handsets over just a few months.   That same period will be crucial for investors.They must decide whether the iPhone is the next Nano, Apple's home-run music player, or the next Newton, its mega-flop personal digital assistant.   So far, they've bet Nano. Apple shares (AAPL) have soared more than 40% since Jan. 9 when the company announced it was going into the smart-phone business; in all they've risen 1,417% going back to May 2003, when Apple revealed that one million tunes had been downloaded from its iTune Website -- a software asset that could play a significant role in any success the iPhone enjoys.   There's no doubt the stock reflects a lot of iPhone success -- at nearly five times sales and more than 30 times future earnings -- and is likely headed into a volatile patch. In fact, the shares bear some resemblance to the iPhone -- very pricey but full of promise. Taking some profits is prudent while waiting to see if sales measure up.   "There's been such hysteria around the phone that it led to what I would regard as a premature increase in the share price," says consultant and former Needham analyst Charlie Wolf, author of the technology newsletter Wolf Bytes.   Even some bulls anticipate a postlaunch stumble in the shares. "There have been letdowns after Apple product launches in the past," says Glen Kacher, a principal of Menlo Park, Calif.-based Integral Capital, which owns an undisclosed stake in Apple.   Walter Price Jr., a technology fund manager for Allianz Capital in San Francisco, says he has been cutting his Apple position, with the idea of rebuilding it for the long haul after shares stop sputtering.   Wolf, too, has sold some shares in his personal account, but is still a long-term bull, looking for shares to hit 135 over the next 12 months.   Another way to protect against the volatility surrounding the iPhone is by using options (see my colleague Steve Sears' Striking Price column on page M8).   There is cause for pause. If a lot of early quality-control problems with the devices arise, for example, sales could suffer and the shares would stumble. If Apple fails to stay on pace to meet its sales goal of three million units for 2007, then shares would also get hit. And if it fails to keep pace next year to sell 10 million units, the same holds true.   How bad could it get? "If the phone was a total flop, it could take the dip down into double digits," Wolf says.   But he doesn't think that will happen. In fact, he suggests the opposite. If Apple can blow through its initial sales goals cleanly -- without reliability or durability problems -- by September or so, the analyst thinks the shares could snap back sooner rather than later. But first, investors will have to ride out the turbulence of the introductory phase as hard-core Apple devotees begin to give way to less-forgiving customers. "You won't have any sustainability in the stock until late summer or fall," says Wolf.   If the launch avoids quality or service glitches, there is likely to be a short supply of handsets for the rest of the year, says Tony Ursillo, an analyst at asset-manager Loomis Sayles. Apple will exploit demand to its advantage by tightening the flow of supply just enough to support the phone's initial high price tags of $499 and $599, and help spur even greater demand, Ursillo says. "You can even look at precedents like previous iPod refreshes and see that when there is supply constraint, it works in the company's favor," Ursillo says.   As important as iPhone's launch is, computer sales will be key to the stock's maintaining its upward trajectory well into 2008. To put things in context, if Apple sells 10 million iPhones in 2008, that would add only $500 million in revenue, or 2% of its $21.6 billion estimated total.   Thus, a big part of the story is the Mac. As Barron's outlined in a cover story last summer ("Bruised but Tasty," July 17, 2006), the addition of Intel-powered computers and this fall's introduction of a new operating system, code-named Leopard, should make Macs more Windows-friendly. The result should be a conversion of Windows users to Macintosh computers, based on the halo effect of the iPod -- and possibly the iPhone. "For the stock to work at these [valuation] levels, that part of the story has to work. Mac has to do great," says Integral's Kacher.   So far, even before the introduction of Leopard -- delayed to accommodate the iPhone launch -- Mac sales have been picking up momentum. Third-party software called Parallels, which allows Macintosh owners to use Windows, has been selling briskly, with nearly a half-million copies of the program sold, Wolf says.   The arrival of Boot Camp should kick-start Mac sales into an even higher gear. The recent Apple software developers' conference confirmed that the game-changing Boot Camp, which enables users to boot into either Mac or Windows, will ship with the new Mac operating system OS 10.5 (Leopold), says Needham analyst John Lynch, who rates Apple a Buy with a $135 target.   To be sure, the iPhone, like the shares, carries risks. It's expensive, has an unconventional keyboard, and is being deployed on AT&T's slower EDGE network. On top of that, corporations are telling their employees -- the biggest users of smart phones -- that they will not buy or support the Apple phones. (Jobs, however, has promised one for every Apple employee.) Plus, mobile handsets are simply more complex than music players or computers, and the industry demands rigorous quality, says Charter Equity telecom analyst Ed Snyder, who does not cover the stock.   "The hardware needs to be bullet-proof, and the software has to be easy to use," Snyder says.   It all comes down to software.   ---   Barron's Online staff writer Tiernan Ray contributed to this story.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: RBS Agrees To Sell 15 Hotels To Robson Asset Management-Paper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS.LN) has agreed to sell 15 hotels, including 12 Hiltons, to Robson Asset Management, a new vehicle set up by Jeremy Robson, the former head of principal finance at Royal Bank of Scotland, The Times reports Saturday without citing sources.   The hotels, which were to have been sold to Vector, are changing hands for slightly more than GBP1.1 billion, the newspaper reports.    Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9413     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 07:14 ET (11:14 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) The Trader: Doubts On Debt Weigh On Stocks
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   In theory, the second half of 2007 should begin quietly. The July 4 holiday beckons, and distractions abound. Except for Friday's jobs report, the flow of economic news will slow to a trickle.   But how stocks behave in a noiseless week can indicate the market's inclination, which lately has become harder to discern. For almost a year, stocks have melted up stubbornly on good and bad news, or even when there's no news. But that hot streak of four winning quarters ended on a discordant note in June, when stocks pulled back to register just their second decline in 13 months.   Last week, investors continued to fret about rising borrowing costs and trouble from leveraged speculation in the debt market, and the extent of such trouble could become clearer soon. With the quarter ended, many hedge funds will begin to give investors an account of their performance, and traders will be straining for a whiff of the kind of tumult that tripped up two hedge funds at Bear Stearns (ticker: BSC).   Nervous investors in junk-bond mutual funds also withdrew more than $400 million last week, while a $3.6 billion financing to help two buyout firms acquire U.S. Foodservice foundered. With stock prices supported by lavish buyouts and bounteous debt, traders will keep an anxious eye to see how this summer's pipeline of junk-bond deals, pegged at about $100 billion, is greeted in the market.   That anxiety is manifested in last week's erratic trading and thwarted advances. While stocks finished the week flat, the major benchmarks pushed repeatedly to intraday highs only to falter and fall. Crude oil ticked to a 10-month high of $70.68 a barrel, but the yield on 10-year Treasuries retreated slightly to 5.034%.   For the week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average crept up 48, or 0.4%, to 13,409. The Standard & Poor's 500 barely eked out a one-point gain to 1503. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 14, or 0.6%, to 2603, while the Russell 2000 index of small stocks lost a point to 834.   The quarterly gains were impressive: The Dow's 8.5% surge marked its best quarter since 2003. The S&P 500 has climbed 5.8% since April 1 and the Nasdaq 7.5%; both have rallied in eight of the past nine quarters. But the quarter ended with a whimper. For the month of June, the Dow fell 1.6%, the S&P 500 fell 1.8%, the Nasdaq gave up 0.05% while the Russell 2000 fell 1.6%.   Uneasiness over a potentially over-levered market was summed up recently by Punk Ziegel analyst Richard Bove, who outlined a wobbly inverted pyramid. At the bottom is real GDP growth of about 1.9% over the past year. On top of that is personal income growth of about 5.8%. But total credit outstanding has increased 8.7%, asset-backed securities have grown 18.7%, while debt held by broker dealers is up more than 26%.   "The growth in real GDP and personal income is supposed to generate the funds necessary to pay the interest on the debt instruments," he notes. When that fails, a financial shock could result.   Still, investors are willing to wait and see. Over the past four years, stocks have overcome a litany of woes to march higher, and bulls see little reason for this time to be different. Record short bets make it hard to paint this market as overly complacent, but it's also hardly as fretful as increasingly shrill market commentary suggests. The consensus gleaned from many money managers' mid-year outlooks remains largely nonplussed, with many penciling in high single-digit gains for the year.   Robert Pavlik, Oaktree Asset Management's chief investment officer and senior portfolio manager, says he would not be surprised by a second-half pullback of 3% to 5% but sees no worse suffering than that. "Market gains will likely be fueled by an increase in business spending and strong global growth, relatively low interest rates and modest stock valuations," he says.   Further support for stocks should come from the market's willingness to buy on dips, robust employment, booming tourism, and increased demand for U.S. goods and services stoked by the weaker greenback. Still, Pavlik's year-end S&P 500 target of 1550, just 3.1% above current levels, suggests less than compelling upside for investors buying today.   "It's a liquidity-driven market, yet there's evidence that access to capital is getting a little more difficult," says Jack Ablin, Harris Private Bank's chief investment officer. Ablin recently fashioned a "liquidity barometer" from credit spreads, the shape of the yield curve, gauges of the market's risk appetite, and even the value of the yen. While these show liquidity to still be abundant, they "are beginning to tighten, suggesting that easy money is getting slightly harder to come by."   That worry showed in a 17% drop in shares of Blackstone Group (BX), the subject of a cautionary Barron's cover story last week. Another sign? Ablin divided the S&P 500 into five groups ranked by their price-to-cash-flow multiples. The cheapest stocks relative to their cash flow have long made the most-coveted buyout targets, and rabid speculation had propelled that cheapest quintile up 11.2% this year -- well ahead of the field. But for the most recent five days ended Thursday, this group pulled back the furthest and declined 1.2%.   Earnings will provide the next test, and here expectations have ticked higher. Analysts forecast second-quarter profit growth of 4.3%, up from less than 3% just two months ago, although bulls hope for growth of 5% to 8%.   The strongest improvement should come from industrials and technology (see story on page 33), while consumer discretionary profits are projected to fall 9%. For all the fretting about the consumer's demise, segments like hotels, restaurants, and electronic retailers have posted strong profit growth -- until recently, when retailers like Best Buy (BBY) missed estimates and trimmed its forecast. Says Thomson Financial analyst David Dropsey: "Now, for the first time in a while, there's more uncertainty about whether weakness from homebuilders and autos will spread."   What worked in the first half of 2007? Construction, mining, railroads, technology, and other beneficiaries of a global economic boom led the market. A Jan. 8 call made here to bet on energy also paid off with the Energy Select SPDR Fund (XLE) rallying 23% since, while the refiner Valero Energy (VLO), flagged here late-February, is up 45% this year. On the other hand, sectors reliant on the American consumer have lagged, with homebuilders, casinos and apparel retailers suffering.   This isn't surprising as the U.S.' share of global gross domestic product continues to slip -- to about 27% from 32% over the past five years. The widening chasm between overseas and domestic earnings is stark: S&P 500 pretax profits derived from foreign operations surged 20% in the first quarter, according to Merrill Lynch, while domestic profits slipped 0.4% -- the slowest since the fourth quarter of 2002.   Things may not change much in the second half. A ranking of countries by annual GDP growth sees the U.S. in the middle of the pack last year but bringing up the rear in 2007. In contrast, Merrill sees some $1.25 trillion of spending on infrastructure in emerging markets over the next three years.   "Our message is to stick with what works," says Merrill's North American economist David Rosenberg. "Ensure the cyclical part of the portfolio retains a global reach, and the domestic segment overweighs the defensive-growth sector."     Two weeks ago, this column questioned why the boxing equipment company Everlast (EVST) had agreed hastily to a seemingly low merger bid from an affiliated licensee (and promptly heard from Everlast's lawyers). Since then, the market has quickly weighed in.   Everlast shares jumped more than 11% Thursday morning after the affiliate, the Hidary Group, disclosed in a regulatory filing that it was amending its buyout offer to $30.55 a share from $26.50. The reason? Another bidder apparently has emerged.   Minutes before Thursday's closing bell, Everlast announced a $168 million pact to be bought by a unit of Sports Direct, a U.K. sports retailer looking to expand stateside. The deal valued shares at 30.   Is this latest jab the best deal for Everlast stockholders? That cannot be properly answered when questions from Round One still linger: Did management conduct an auction for the company? What steps were taken to seek the best possible price? Management said Thursday it was "pleased with the terms of this transaction and believe it is in the best interests of the company's stockholders." Funny, it said the exact same thing of the previous offer.   Not to be outdone, Hidary on Friday upped its bid for a second time in quick succession -- to $31.25 a share. Everlast shares climbed another 9% to trade above 32. After Friday's close, the Sports Direct unit raised its offer to 33. Ladies and gentlemen, we have a fight on our hands.     Changing something as fundamental as a name can often signal a bigger transformation to come. Demetria Guynes morphed into Demi Moore. Brad's Drink became Pepsi-Cola. And would Google (GOOG) have colonized the world if it was still called BackRub?   On July 1, the sporting goods company Collegiate Pacific marked its new fiscal year by changing its name to Sport Supply Group, and swapping its ticker symbol from BOO to RBI. But the transformation should go deeper than that.   The small Dallas company supplies sports equipment to schools, teams and the non-retail market through catalogs, the Internet, and its sales team. The sports run the gamut from archery to wrestling, and the goods range from baseball bats to bleachers and goal posts.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Commodities Corner: Corn Prices Get Crushed
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Angie Pointer   The heartland issued a collective gasp Friday, as farmers and traders absorbed a sharply higher, new estimate of corn-planted acreage in the U.S. -- versus a starkly shrunken soybean figure.   The huge pop in corn plantings sent the crop's Chicago Board of Trade prices down Friday, while soy prices rallied. And on the week, December corn fell 30.75 cents a bushel, to settle at $3.5075, while the November soybean contract rose 51 cents a bushel, to $8.8175. Both contract months represent the fall harvest.   In the near-term, analysts see CBOT soybean futures rising further. Meanwhile, more declines in corn futures are expected near-term, as fears are quelled about shortages of corn for use in the ethanol and livestock industries.   The U.S. Department of Agriculture's latest, nearly 93-million-acre forecast for corn -- an astonishing 18.6% higher than last year and the highest planted area since 1944 -- jostled for commodity headlines with the news that soybean planting was down about 15% from last year, or about 11.4 million acres, from the year-ago, to 64 million, the smallest planted area since 1995.   The implications for futures prices, the biofuels industry and food producers are far-reaching. Says Don Roose, president of brokerage U.S. Commodities, "We need more [soybean] acres in South America," to meet biodiesel demand. He adds that CBOT soybean futures need to reach about $9 a bushel to spur planting in South America -- particularly by megaproducer Brazil, as soybean prices are dollar-denominated, while the real's value is falling.   Brazilian analysts agree. "If prices go to $10 a bushel, and that's a real possibility, you will have farmers planting soybeans in clay pots and flower vases," says Flavio Franca, a soy-market analyst for private consulting firm Safras & Mercado.   Analysts in Brazil said that, prior to the new data, the soybean area was expected to increase by 5%, from the 20 million hectares (49.4 million acres) planted in 2006-'07. Now, the prospect of higher prices could stimulate increased Brazilian plantings yet more.   Regarding corn, analysts say that the acreage figure suggests U.S. farmers could produce up to a 13-billion-bushel corn crop, as long as the weather remains favorable to plant development and maximum yields are achieved. Ultimately, this level of increase provides a much-needed cushion for the corn market. "You can have some weather problems, and still have a good corn crop," Roose says.   David Driscoll, analyst with Citigroup Investment Research, says the declining corn prices create a bullish scenario for the corn-processor and ethanol-producer Archer Daniels Midland (ticker: ADM). The expected jump in the South American soybean crop is also seen as a positive over the long term for agribusiness company, Bunge (BG), analysts say. A decline in corn prices will also help poultry producers such as Tyson Foods (TSN) and Pilgrim's Pride (PPC), among others, since the grain is a primary component of chicken feed, as JPMorgan analyst Pablo Zuniac points out in a research note.   And with the latest acreage figures published, those with an interest in grains are going to be looking hard at factors that affect final production -- namely weather -- right up until harvest time, analysts say.   ---   Angie Pointer is assistant commodities editor for Dow Jones Newswires, Chicago. Kenneth Rapoza, a reporter in Sao Paulo, Brazil contributed to this report.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Follow-up: Lionsgate's Star Will Rise Yet Again
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   When investors get confused about a company, it's almost always bad for the shares. So it is right now with Vancouver-based, independent Lionsgate Entertainment. The spoiler: Fiscal fourth-quarter earnings dropped to $25 million, or 19 cents a share, on  $331.6 million in revenue. And while the Friday opening of Lionsgate-distributed Sicko, by Michael Moore -- about what many consider the real-life horror story of the U.S. health-care system -- may be getting more buzz than the buckets-of-guts Saw movies, it's not expected to bring much box-office bling.   Wall Street foresaw earnings of about 22 cents. Worse still, in a conference call, CEO Jon Feltheimer warned that Lions Gate (ticker: LGF) expected to report a loss of about $50 million in the new fiscal year, a considerable reverse from analysts' targets of $50-million-plus in profit. So the shares fell from a $12 peak, to 11.   But Lionsgate hasn't yet run out of red carpet. As we noted in our bullish story "The Little Studio that Could" (July 10, 2006), profits and earnings are wobbly indicators at Lionsgate, since movie releases cause big, sudden earnings swings, and accounting rules require the company to book production costs as they occur -- way earlier.   Much of the fourth-quarter shortfall was driven by a 15% year-over-year rise in direct operating expenses, along with a 6% increase in general costs, both due to the fact that Lionsgate is shooting a combination of both more movies and more expensive movies (which tend to make more money).   Since we wrote about Lionsgate, the stock has risen nearly 50%, from what was then a low of 8.60. We still see more growth to come, and three analysts see the shares headed above 15.   Lionsgate has a very healthy balance sheet, with about $289 million in cash and short-term investments. It continues to spin off from its franchise of horror movies; the coming releases of War, Hostel II and Saw IV are expected to deliver.   On top of that, it's been among the faster movers into new methods of digital delivery: The 15 movies that Lionsgate made available earlier this year to Microsoft's Xbox Live helped boost digital revenue 50%, while Feltheimer notes that video-on-demand sales for Employee of the Month "exceeded $3 million on a film that grossed about $27 million at the domestic box office." The company has, he explains, "nearly a dozen active agreements in place for digital delivery" of its content with major companies, including Best Buy (BBY).   Finally, Lionsgate is one of the last remaining pure-play entertainment companies, and has been rumored to be a takeover candidate, especially on the strength of its library of more than 11,000  titles, including such gems as Rambo, American Psycho, and The Blair Witch Project.   Says Feltheimer: "There are no more libraries out there to be bought."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited by Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Basin Water   -- BWTR-NNM     Buy   -- Price 7.74 on June 26   by Nollenberger Capital Partners     Initiating coverage with Buy rating and 12-month target of 12.80. We estimate the company can grow its revenue at a 40% compound annual rate through [decade's] end...with even greater growth off small base for earnings. Customers include Aqua America, American Water, California Water Services, Arizona-American Water, and American States Water. Basin's patented process [to bring contaminated groundwater to drinking-water standards] employs multiple beds controlled by a computer. The patent has 17 years to run. The process produces one-tenth the waste of a conventional ion-exchange plant. Although upfront cost of a Basin Water system is about 20% higher than competing [systems'], the cost over a 10-year contract is about 50% less. If new technology were to emerge, we believe it would take years of testing to secure regulatory approval. The company ended the 1Q07 with cash of $51.2 million/nearly $2.60 a share. We expect BWTR to be cash-neutral in '07 and generate free cash in '08.     CommVault Systems   -- CVLT-NNM     Market Outperform   -- Price 16.58 on June 26   by JMP Securities     Initiating coverage with Market Outperform and 12-month target of 20, or 21% upside from current level. CommVault is a leading provider of storage software solutions, including flagship product Galaxy Backup and Recovery. We believe CommVault is well-positioned in the storage-software market, given its unique technical architecture, comprehensive data-management platform, upcoming product cycle and solid distribution relationships. We are introducing our fiscal-year '08 non-GAAP earnings-per- share estimate of 57 cents, one cent above consensus. We are introducing our FY09 non-GAAP EPS estimate of 72 cents, 2 cents above consensus. Our price target places CommVault at a calendar 2008 price-earnings multiple of 30 times, a premium to its peer group, but only a slight premium to its estimated earnings-growth rate of 29% from calendar-year '07 to CY08.     Implant Sciences   -- IMX-Amex     Neutral   -- Price 1.80 on June 26   by Taglich Brothers     Implant Sciences, headquartered in Wakefield, Mass., develops, acquires and commercializes ion-implantation and thin-film-coating technology with applications in medical devices, semiconductor manufacturing and trace-explosive detection. Maintaining Neutral: The explosives-detection business has significant longer-term upside potential, but until it shows more consistent revenue gains and product-development progress, IMX is unlikely to outperform the market in next 12 months....With release of benchtop-mounted Quantum Sniffer and detection portal for head-to-toe passenger screening, both still in development, explosive-detection systems revenue gains might accelerate. Citing intensifying competition, IMX sold its Accurel Int'l. semiconductor business for $12.5 million...[which] should improve liquidity, offset cash burn through FY08 and provide funding for expansion of explosives-detection...[but the sale] reduces annual revenue by $8.5 million and lowers gross margins three to five percentage points...operations are likely to remain unprofitable through FY09...[but should not require] further financing.     Meadowbrook Insurance Group   -- MIG-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 10.20 on June 26   by Friedman Billings Ramsey     Upgraded from Market Perform. MIG shares are down 17% from 52-week high in October '06. At 1.4 times [book value], we believe the shares are attractive, particularly given the 28% upside to our new price target and the [rating upgrade] from A.M. Best, a [credit-rating organization focused on financial-services, including banking and insurance]...In addition to [book value] growth, we believe there's room for multiple expansion...as top-line growth increases. In 1Q07, gross and net premiums grew...0.6% and 3.7%, respectively. Despite slow growth, management maintained its '07 full-year premium forecast during 1Q07 earnings call, implying premium volume will accelerate for remainder of '07, with mid-teens growth rate...[and] expand further in '08, as A.M. Best upgrade benefits...are realized. Potential acquisitions of fee income-generating businesses and [managing general agents] should lead to earnings growth....Our new 13 target is based on a 1.86 times peer-group average multiple to book value of $7.02.     South Financial Group   -- TSFG-NNM     Hold   -- Price 23.21 on June 28   by Sandler O'Neill     Reducing our '07 EPS estimate by two cents to $1.35 and '08 EPS estimate by five cents to $1.56.... We expect TSFG to report 2Q07 operating EPS of 33 cents, up from 30 cents in 1Q07 and down 15.4%, year-over-year...Target [cut] by 50 cents to $24.50, owing mainly to lower peer valuations.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Betting On The Newest Stocks
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra Defotis   If the queue of companies lined up to go public in the second half of 2007 says anything about expectations for the stock market, the chorus of doomsayers may need to rethink their song. The number of initial public offerings, or IPOs, completed year-to-date is up about 25% from the first half of 2006, while the backlog of deals in waiting is valued at $17.6 billion, around the same level as last year. More important, the quality of companies in the pipeline suggests somenew stocks will be big winners.   It has paid to invest in IPOs this year; the average new issue has returned about 12% since its offering, well above the mid-single-digit returns logged by the Dow Jones industrials and other market measures. That is a reflection, in part, of the financial health of companies coming public today. Another indication of their attractiveness to investors: more than 75% of this year's new issues priced at or above the range expected by hopeful executives and underwriters.   IPOs raised $40.7 billion in 2006, says Dealogic, whose data exclude offerings priced below $5 a share; special-purpose companies, or SPACs, and unit offerings. The Class of 2007 is on track to match that total, having raised $20 billion so far, excluding the Blackstone Group's (ticker: BX) $4.1 billion sale of units June 21. Ironically, Blackstone hasn't joined the gallery of winners; its shares priced at 31, popped to 38 in their first day of trading and then fell to 30 amid concerns about valuation and potential changes to the federal tax code that could clip the firm's future earnings. (For more on the deal, see last week's Barron's cover story, "Top of the Market.")   The pace of new-issue filings has quickened in recent months, spurred by a healthy economy and stock market, and a rash of offerings seeking to capitalize on technology and telecommunications innovations. Tech and energy offerings are up this year, and the buzz surrounding Blackstone has boosted interest in financial-sector issues. Rival buyout firms including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Carlyle Group and Citadel Investment are thought to be eyeing public offerings of their own.   A year ago health care was vying for the IPO spotlight, but many young biotech shares have since turned in a lackluster performance.   Fueling demand for IPOs is the profitability of the companies coming public. Roughly 70% of this year's new stocks were issued by companies operating in the black or on the verge of doing so, something all but unheard of during the dot-com -- and IPO -- booms of the late 1990s. Also, institutional investors are on the prowl for new names, as more public companies slip behind closed doors via corporate takeovers and leveraged buyouts.   But the door swings both ways. Says Linda Killian, manager of the IPO Plus Aftermarket Fund, with $19 million of assets, "We are looking to increase our holdings in technology and the health-care area. A number of companies that went private are coming public again."   Fresh from its own offering, Blackstone is set to spin out one of its holdings, Orbitz Worldwide, the online consumer-travel service. One of the larger deals in the pipeline, Orbitz hopes to raise $750 million.   Blackstone got Orbitz when it purchased Cendant's Travelport businesses, which also include Galileo, an electronic travel-services company. It's a bullish sign for Orbitz that Expedia (EXPE), a competitor, is about to buy back its own shares near all-time highs, says Richard Peterson, an IPO expert at Thomson Financial.   Another Web-based company, Dice Holdings, hopes to raise $200 million in coming months. The New York concern operates employment Websites for recruiters and companies seeking experts in technology, engineering and finance. Given the number of civilians employed as consultants to the U.S. military in Iraq and elsewhere, Dice also is well positioned with ClearanceJobs.com, aimed at people with U.S. government security clearance.   With oil prices near $70 a barrel, some energy issues in registration, such as Concho Resources, an exploration company, and Stallion Oilfield Services, look promising. Other deals in the pipeline include unit offerings for oil and gas limited partnerships, which have been growing in popularity. Oil prices would have to fall precipitously for these prospective offerings to be postponed or canceled.   Still other companies seek to cash in on the growing demand for alternative fuels. Seattle-based Imperium Renewables, which is developing biodiesel production technology, hopes to raise $345 million. And Global Energy, based in Cincinnati and run by a former Procter & Gamble executive, hopes to raise $350 million. The company recently signed a 10-year deal to provide synthetic gas to P&G Paper Products.   Chinese solar listings were sizzling performers in the first half of 2007, but fund manager Killian thinks the cycle has peaked. JA Solar Holdings (JASO), which makes solar cells for the Chinese market, has soared 129%, to 34.40, since its February IPO.   Tech and telecom issues have been stars this year; tech IPOs have returned an average of 27%, and telecom issues 14%. One sign of the market's healthy appetite for tech deals was Wednesday's 66% first-day pop in shares of Data Domain (DDUP), a data-recovery concern that finished the session at 24.95. It boasts the year's second-best stock-market debut after Fortress Investment Group (FIG), which rallied 68% in its first day of trading in February.   Thomson's Peterson questions the prospects for Virgin Mobile's U.S. IPO, likely to price later this year. With Wall Street riveted by the introduction of Apple's iPhone, shares of the global mobile-phone service provider could suffer.   Health-care IPOs did poorly in the year's first half, especially those of pharmaceutical and biotechnology concerns. Among the year's worst performers to date, stent-maker Xtent (XTNT), came out of the gate in January at 16 a share. But the stock has plummeted 35%, to 10.35, amid growing concerns about the safety of drug-coated stents.   Among the biggest deals expected this year is a $2 billion U.S. offering by Cosan, Brazil's largest sugar and ethanol producer. The company trades in Sao Paulo and now is seeking a New York Stock Exchange listing. Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) is rumored to be considering an offer for the company, which should benefit from consolidation among Brazilian producers as global demand for sugar and ethanol increases.   Roughly 20% of this year's IPOs have been floated by non-U.S. companies. In addition to JA Solar, Acorn International (ATV), a Chinese marketing concern, has been a strong performer in the aftermarket. The stock came public in May at 15.50 a share and finished last week around 25.   Some foreign deals have hit rough waters, too, including Xinhua Finance Media (XFML), a unit of China's Xinhua Finance. Its shares are down 33%, to 8.67, from their March offering price of 13, amid controversy about executive departures and the past financial dealings of certain controlling shareholders (Asian Trader, Barron's May 28).   So far this year, the London market has claimed 25% of global new-stock listings, Hong Kong another 11%, according to Thomson Financial. U.S. exchanges accounted for 20% of deal proceeds.   "The Chinese and some South American companies are [coming to the U.S.], but not the European and Indian companies," Killian says. "Sarbanes-Oxley is one reason, and alternative markets in Hong Kong and London are a lot more liquid than they were five years ago."   More foreign offerings could make their way to U.S. exchanges by early fall if the Securities and Exchange Commission succeeds with a proposal to allow foreign companies to state profits solely according to international accounting standards. Companies based abroad currently must file a second set of books to comply with U.S rules.   The stock market's continued health is key to the IPO market's success. If interest rates rise and investors' appetite for risk diminishes, the window for deals will slam shut. For now, however, the window is wide open, which spells good news for the issuers of new stock, and the buyers.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Isle of Capri Casinos, Inc. Brings New Brand to Waterloo
Story: ST. LOUIS, June 30 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Isle of Capri Casinos, Inc. (Nasdaq: ISLE) has opened its latest casino, the isle casino & hotel at waterloo, bringing the Company's newest brand to Iowa.     "It is exciting to see "the isle" brand move to Waterloo where guests can enjoy the hottest casino action with the latest and greatest slot machines and action-packed table games, a luxurious night's sleep and the best restaurants," said Bernard Goldstein, chairman and chief executive officer. "Our customers are looking for a total entertainment experience and the isle casino & hotel at waterloo will not only meet their expectations, but exceed their wildest dreams."     "the isle casino & hotel at waterloo" opened at 7:00 pm following a celebration with local dignitaries. The property features over 1,100 slot machines, 35 table games and three restaurants including the signature tropical-themed buffet, Tradewinds Marketplace and the Company-branded Farraddays' steakhouse (scheduled to open later this summer), as well as a 194-room hotel and 5,000 square feet of convention space. Later this year a nightclub, spa and pool will be added.     "the isle" brand will expand again later this summer when the Company opens its casino in Coventry, England.     Isle of Capri Casinos, Inc., founded in 1992, is dedicated to providing its customers with an exceptional gaming and entertainment experience at each of its 18 casino properties. The Company owns and operates casinos in Biloxi, Lula and Natchez, Mississippi; Lake Charles, Louisiana; Bettendorf, Davenport, Marquette and Waterloo, Iowa; Boonville, Caruthersville and Kansas City, Missouri and a casino and harness track in Pompano Beach, Florida. The Company also operates and has a 57 percent ownership interest in two casinos in Black Hawk, Colorado. Isle of Capri Casinos' international gaming interests include a casino that it operates in Freeport, Grand Bahama, a casino under development in Coventry, England, and a two-thirds ownership interest in casinos in Dudley and Wolverhampton, England.     There are four Isle of Capri Casinos brands including "the isle," Isle of Capri, Colorado Central Station and Rhythm City, providing over 16,000 slot machines, 550 table games and 3000 hotel rooms for our guests' enjoyment.     This press release may be deemed to contain forward-looking statements, which are subject to change. These forward-looking statements may be significantly impacted, either positively or negatively by various factors, including without limitation, licensing, and other regulatory approvals, financing sources, development and construction activities, costs and delays, weather, permits, competition and business conditions in the gaming industry. The forward-looking statements are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in or implied by the statements herein.     Additional information concerning potential factors that could affect the Company's financial condition, results of operations and expansion projects, is included in the filings of the Company with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including, but not limited to, its Form 10-K for the most recently ended fiscal year. Headline: UPDATE: Canada Telecom BCE Agrees To C$51.7B Buyout
Story: (Updates with details, quotes)     TORONTO (AP)--BCE Inc. (BCE), Canada's largest telecommunications company, said Saturday it has reached an agreement to be bought by a group led by the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan for C$51.7 billion, making it the largest takeover in Canadian history.   The Ontario Teachers Pension Plan Board in co-operation with U.S.-based Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners, LLC won out over several other bidders, BCE said in a statement.   "It is gratifying to see that BCE's Board of Directors shares our vision for this initiative, and we are honored to lead the largest buyout transaction in Canadian corporate history," Jim Leech, senior vice-president of Teachers' Private Capital, the investment wing of the pension plan, said in the statement.   The pension plan was BCE's largest shareholder with a 6.8% stake. Leech noted that the plan has been a major BCE shareholder since the early 1990s   The investor group will acquire all of the common shares of BCE not already owned by Teachers for an offer price of C$42.75 per common share.   The all-cash transaction is valued at C$51.7 billion, including C$16.9 billion in debt, preferred equity and minority interests.   The Toronto-based Ontario Teachers Pension Plan - with assets of C$106 billion in 2006 - invests and administers the retirement funds for Ontario's 167,000 teachers and 104,000 retired teachers. Leech said BCE's headquarters will remain in Montreal.   BCE had other potential bidders, including New York-based Cerberus Capital Management LP with billionaire Hong Kong-based, Canadian citizen Richard Li's Pacific Century Group, and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board with backing from U.S. buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co.   Telus Corp. (TU) - Canada's second-largest telecom company - pulled out of the bidding last Tuesday.   BCE, which has more than 54,000 employees, had annual revenue of C$17.7 billion in 2006. It has 18.2 million customer connections, including 5.8 million wireless subscribers, 8.64 million phone lines, 1.94 million internet subscribers and 1.82 million satellite television subscribers. Besides Bell Canada, Bell Canada International and wireless telecom companies, BCE holdings include interest in CTVglobemedia, one of the Canada's biggest media companies.   "This proposed transaction concludes a comprehensive and disciplined review of the company's strategic alternatives launched April 17," Richard J. Currie, BCE's chairman of the board, said in the statement. "It will deliver substantial value creation for our shareholders. In addition, a majority of the equity will be owned by Canadians."   BCE chief executive Michael Sabia resisted suggestions of a takeover in the past, in the belief that his slimming and focusing of BCE, including an end to its conglomerate structure and a planned return to the Bell Canada name, would end a long period of flat stock-market performance.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 11:07 ET (15:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: HK Shui On Land's Unit Sells Stakes In 3 Units For CNY2.12B
Story: HONG KONG (Dow Jones)--Chinese developer Shui On Land Ltd. (0272.HK) said late Friday its wholly owned unit Shui On Development Hldgs. agreed to sell part of its stake in three units to two strategic investors for a total of CNY2.12 billion.   The company said the proceeds from the stake sales will be used for general working capital.   Hong Kong-listed Shui On Land said Shui On Development agreed to sell a 9.9% interest in Chongqing developer Score High Ltd. to Winnington Capital Ltd. for CNY503 million. After the transaction, Shui On Development will own 80.2% of Score High.   Shui On Development also agreed to sell a 25% stake in Wuhan developer Fieldcity Investments Ltd. to Trophy Property Development L.P. for CNY1.25 billion. Following the transaction, Shui On Development will own 75% of  Fieldcity Investments.   In the third transaction, Shui On Development agreed to sell a 49% stake of Shanghai developer Portspin Ltd. to Trophy Property Development for CNY364 million. Following completion of the sale, Shui On Development will own 51% of Portspin.     -By Lorraine Luk, Dow Jones Newswires; 852-2802-7002; lorraine.luk@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 02:00 ET (06:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE:China Ex-Bk Regulator Is Everbright Grp Chmn-Official
Story: (Updates with quote from Jiang and adds details throughout)     By Rick Carew and Rose Yu   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     SHANGHAI (Dow Jones)--China has named a former banking regulator, Tang Shuangning, to be chairman of China Everbright Group, the parent of China Everbright Bank Co., a senior regulatory official said Saturday.   The appointment of the former vice chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission is a step toward the reorganization of China Everbright Group as its banking unit, China Everbright Bank, awaits a government capital injection.   China Everbright Group, a state-owned financial conglomerate under the State Council, is the bank's largest shareholder with a 24.16% stake. Its Hong Kong-listed unit, China Everbright Ltd. (0165.HK), owns a 21.4% stake in the bank.   Jiang Dingzhi, vice chairman and deputy partysecretary of the CBRC, also said that the reform of Agricultural Bank of China is "still under study."   "Agricultural Bank of China's reform is a special case because its historical burden is relatively heavy," he said. "Its situation is different from Industrial & Commercial Bank of China Ltd. and other banks, ... so its difficult to say the size of its capital injection."   Revamping Agricultural Bank is the final piece of the puzzle for the country's state-bank overhauls, which kicked off in December 2003 with Central Huijin Investment Co. injecting$45 billion into two of Agricultural Bank's state bank rivals - China Construction Bank Corp. and Bank of China Ltd. The subsequent listings of three of China's so-called Big Four state banks raised $42.3 billion - riding a wave of China interest to exceed expectations.   Jiang said on the sidelines of a banking forum in Shanghai that international accounting firm Deloitte & Touche had already completed an audit of the Agricultural Bank, but the audit by the Chinese government audit agency, the National Audit Office, is still ongoing.   The two audits are viewed by analysts as an important step in establishing how much money the government should inject into Agricultural Bank of China to recapitalize it.     -By Rick Carew and Rose Yu, Dow Jones Newswires; 8621 6120-1200; rick.carew@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 02:24 ET (06:24 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) The Trader: Doubts On Debt Weigh On -2-
Story: Shares climbed 6% Friday to 9.71, but are still off 10% over the past year as the company struggled to integrate a recent merger. But the sweatiest work may be behind, as management has steered the company to a new technology platform, made its catalog unit more efficient, and consolidated manufacturing functions. A stock overhang also has dissipated after a former CEO sold his holding to Carlson Capital, a Dallas investment firm that has stockpiled a 14.3% stake.   Meanwhile, the institutional sports market is growing quietly but steadily. Analysts expect the company to earn 72 cents a share in 2008 -- up from 46 cents in 2007 and 29 cents in 2006. Shares trade at about 13.5 times forward earnings.   Earnings for the just-ended quarter could still suffer slightly from integration expenses, but sales are ticking up. "We see potential for positive news flow over the coming months," notes Oppenheimer analyst Christopher Jones, who thinks fiscal 2009 per-share earnings could reach $1. And "while the company is not officially for sale, we believe that the openness of the board to potential deals provides a floor." Headline: : World Series of Poker(R) Expands Start of 2007 Main Event To Four Days
Story: LAS VEGAS--(BUSINESS WIRE)--June 30, 2007--   The World Series of Poker has added a fourth start day for the WSOP Main Event, which begins July 6, WSOP officials said today.     The Main Event - a $10,000 buy-in No-Limit Hold'Em World Championship - traditionally draws the largest fields in poker. Last year, 8,773 players competed for the $12 million top prize and coveted WSOP gold bracelet.     "We want to ensure that we're able to provide a comfortable experience for all players who want to enter the Main Event," said Jack Effel, WSOP tournament director. "Adding a fourth start day will allow us to do that."     Players who pre-register for the Main Event will be able to choose Day 1A, 1B, 1C or 1D - July 6, 7, 8 and 9 - as their start day. July 9 was originally scheduled as a break day.     Effel said there will be two Day 2s - 2A and 2B - on July 10 and 11. Main Event play starts at 12 noon each day, beginning July 6.     The 2007 World Series of Poker Presented by Milwaukee's Best Light, the world's richest sporting event, began June 1 at the Rio(R) All-Suite Hotel & Casino in Las Vegas. More information on the tournament is available at www.worldseriesofpoker.com.     The WSOP is operated by an affiliate of Harrah's Entertainment, Inc. (NYSE:HET), the world's largest operator of casino-entertainment resorts. Since its beginning in Reno, Nevada, USA, nearly 70 years ago, Harrah's has grown through the development of new properties, expansions and acquisitions, and now owns or manages 50 casino resorts on four continents. The company's properties operate primarily under the Caesars, Harrah's and Horseshoe brand names; Harrah's also owns and operates the London Clubs International family of casinos and the World Series of Poker tournament. Harrah's Entertainment is focused on building loyalty and value with its customers through a unique combination of great service, excellent products, unsurpassed distribution, operational excellence and technology leadership. The company is committed to reinvesting in the communities in which it operates.     More information about Harrah's is available at its Web site -- www.harrahs.com.
