Headline: =WSJ: Canada's BCE Agrees To Be Acquired For $48.5B
Story: By Sarah Childress     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     Canadian telecommunications operator BCE Inc. (BCE.T)  said Saturday it agreed to be acquired by the investment arm of Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners Inc. and Madison Dearborn Partners, for $48.5 billion.   The move marks the largest buyout in the country's history and the telecoms industry globally.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   The deal includes $15.9 billion in debt, preferred equity and minority interests. Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan is already BCE's largest shareholder. Under the deal, Providence will purchase BCE's shares for C$42.75, or $40.15, a 40% premium over the average first-quarter share price before it rose in late March amid rumors of a buyout.   On Friday, BCE's shares were priced at $37.79 in 4 p.m. composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange.   With a market capitalization of $30 billion, BCE dominates the telecom market in Eastern Canada, selling fixed-line, wireless, high-speed Internet and video services. The company's stock had stagnated in recent years as the company struggled to stay competitive. BCE had trouble signing up subscribers to its Bell Wireless cellphone unit and its landline division lost access lines to cheaper cable providers. Meanwhile, smaller rivals Telus Corp. (TU) and Rogers Communications (RCI) both saw overall growth. In April, Teachers began agitating for a sale.   BCE was widely expected to be taken over by its leading rival, Telus Corp. But in a surprise decision Monday, Telus decided not to submit a bid, citing "inadequacies" in the bidding process. Some observers say that Telus could still enter a hostile bid for its rival, but could be deterred by a hefty breakup fee. Telus could also wait until BCE is split into more profitable components and snatch up the pieces it wants, such as the Bell Wireless division, analysts say.   That left three major bidders to submit plans to BCE's board on Friday. Aside from Teachers, Cerberus Capital Management and the Hospitals of Ontario Pension Plan submited a bid, as well as the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., despite a last-minute pullout of partners Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec in Montreal and Onex Corp. All are major Canadian funds partnered with U.S. private-equity firms because according to federal law, foreign companies can own no more than 46.67% of telecom providers.   It also marks another major deal in a crescendo of buyouts in which private-equity companies take on increasingly greater risks in shorter time frames, looking for profits in a matter of months, not years. "The plan in private-equity is to go after bigger and bigger deals and this is yet another level," says Shahid Khan, a partner at Interactive Broadband Consulting Group.   By Sarah Childress, The Wall Street Journal     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 17:37 ET (21:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : BCE Reaches Definitive Agreement to be Acquired By Investor Group Led by Teachers, Providence and Madison - BCE Board Recommends Shareholders Accept C$42.75 (US$40.13) Per Share Offer
Story: - Offer is 40% premium over "undisturbed share price" - Closing targeted for first quarter, 2008       MONTREAL, June 30 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ - BCE (TSX/NYSE: BCE) today announced that the company has entered into a definitive agreement for BCE to be acquired by an investor group led by Teachers Private Capital, the private investment arm of the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners Inc. and Madison Dearborn Partners, LLC. The all-cash transaction is valued at C$51.7 billion (US$48.5 billion), including C$16.9 billion (US$15.9 billion) of debt, preferred equity and minority interests. The BCE Board of Directors unanimously recommends that shareholders vote to accept the offer.     Under the terms of the transaction, the investor group will acquire all of the common shares of BCE not already owned by Teachers for an offer price of C$42.75 per common share and all preferred shares at the prices set forth in the attached schedule. Financing for the transaction is fully committed through a syndicate of banks acting on behalf of the purchaser. The purchase price represents a 40% premium over the undisturbed average trading price of BCE common shares in the first quarter of 2007, prior to the possibility of a privatization transaction surfacing publicly. The transaction values BCE at 7.8 times EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) for the 12-month period ending March 31, 2007.     "This proposed transaction concludes a comprehensive and disciplined review of the company's strategic alternatives launched April 17," said Richard J. Currie, Chairman of the Board of BCE. "It will deliver substantial value creation for our shareholders. In addition, a majority of the equity will be owned by Canadians."     "The transaction delivers to our shareholders the economic benefit of the work done to focus on our core business and to strengthen Bell with a new cost structure and new competitive capabilities," said Michael Sabia, President and CEO of BCE. "All members of the investor group have outstanding track records in building strong and resilient enterprises and they share our commitment to customers, our employees and the communities we serve."     "It is gratifying to see that BCE's Board of Directors shares our vision for this initiative, and we are honoured to lead the largest buyout transaction in Canadian corporate history," said Jim Leech, Senior Vice-President, Teachers' Private Capital, noting that Teachers has been a major BCE shareholder since the early 1990s. "The Board has recognized our commitment to BCE's ongoing growth potential, through our proposed investment strategy. We made it clear in our proposal that we have carefully considered the potential for BCE and its ongoing status as a Canadian icon. We strongly believe that all BCE shareholders, Canadian consumers, and employees, including senior management, who will continue to direct the company from its headquarters in Montreal, will benefit from this transaction. We look forward to working together with BCE to make this a reality."     "This is a unique opportunity to contribute to and participate in the growth of one of the world's most significant communications companies," said Jonathan M. Nelson, Chief Executive Officer of Providence Equity Partners. "BCE offers state of the art services through its sophisticated network that extends throughout Canada. We look forward to working with BCE's talented management and employees and our partners to build on the strong platform that is in place for the benefit of all of the company's stakeholders."     The equity ownership of BCE would be as follows: Teachers Private Capital 52%, Providence 32%, Madison Dearborn 9% and other Canadian investors 7%.     The purchaser has obtained a debt commitment to finance the transaction subject to usual terms for these types of financings. The purchaser anticipates requiring BCE, Bell Canada and Bell Mobility to redeem outstanding redeemable debentures maturing up to August 2010 pursuant to their terms as of and subject to the closing of the transaction. The acquisition debt financing would become an obligation of BCE and be guaranteed by BCE's then subsidiaries (other than Bell Aliant Regional Communications Income Fund and Northwestel Inc.). As to Bell Canada, the purchaser's financing would comply as to ranking and security with the then existing Bell Canada debentures and medium term notes issued under the 1976 and 1997 indentures. In addition, the purchaser has obtained commitments to make available a combination of facilities in order to support the ongoing liquidity needs for the company.     The transaction is subject to the customary approvals, including CRTC approval for the transfer of Bell's broadcast license, and Industry Canada with respect to the transfer of spectrum licenses.     The transaction includes a break-up fee of C$800 million (US$751 million), payable by BCE in certain circumstances and a reverse break-up fee of C$1 billion payable by the purchaser in certain circumstances. The transaction will be completed through a plan of arrangement, which will require the approval of two-thirds of outstanding common and preferred shares, voting as a class. Shareholders will be asked to vote on the transaction at a special meeting, the details of which will be announced in due course. The company anticipates that the transaction will be completed in the first quarter of next year.     A proxy circular will be prepared and mailed to shareholders over the coming months providing shareholders with important information about the transaction. A material change report, which provides more details on the transaction, will be filed with the Canadian securities commissions and with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and will be available at www.sedar.com and at www.sec.gov.     Legal advisors to BCE are Davies, Ward Phillips & Vineberg, Stikeman Elliott, and Sullivan & Cromwell. The bid process was led by Goldman, Sachs and Co. BMO Capital Markets, CIBC Capital Markets and RBC Capital Markets also acted as financial advisors to the company. Greenhill and Co. provided independent advice to the Strategic Oversight Committee of the BCE Board of Directors. The Board received fairness opinions regarding the consideration to be paid for common and preferred shares from the company's financial advisors.     Legal advisors to the investor group are Weil, Gotshal & Manges and Goodmans. Citi is serving as lead mergers & acquisitions advisor to the consortium. Other financial advisors include Deutsche Banc, Royal Bank of Scotland and TD Securities.                                       SCHEDULE A                     BCE PREFERRED SHARES - PURCHASE PRICES        The cash considerations payable to the holders of the preferred shares      are as follows:        -------------------------------------------------------------------------          First Preferred Shares               Consideration Per Share      -------------------------------------------------------------------------                Series R                             $25.65 (x)                Series S                             $25.50 (x)                Series T                             $25.77 (x)                Series Y                             $25.50 (x)                Series Z                             $25.25 (x)                Series AA                            $25.76 (x)                Series AC                            $25.76 (x)                Series AE                            $25.50 (x)                Series AF                            $25.41 (x)                Series AG                            $25.56 (x)                Series AH                            $25.50 (x)                Series AI                            $25.87 (x)      -------------------------------------------------------------------------        (x)Together with accrued but unpaid dividends to the Effective Date.        About BCE Inc.       BCE is Canada's largest communications company, providing the most comprehensive and innovative suite of communication services to residential and business customers in Canada. Under the Bell brand, the Company's services include local, long distance and wireless phone services, high-speed and wireless Internet access, IP-broadband services, information and communications technology services (or value-added services) and direct-to-home satellite and VDSL television services. Other BCE holdings include Telesat Canada, a pioneer and world leader in satellite operations and systems management, and an interest in CTVglobemedia, Canada's premier media company. BCE shares are listed in Canada and the United States.        About Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan     With more than $16 billion in assets, Teachers' Private Capital is one of North America's largest private investors, providing equity and mezzanine debt capital for large and mid-sized companies, venture capital for developing industries, and financing for a growing portfolio of infrastructure and timberland assets worldwide. The CDN$106 billion Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan is the largest single-profession pension plan in Canada. It is an independent corporation responsible for investing the fund and administering the pensions of Ontario's 271,000 active and retired teachers.        About Providence Equity Partners Inc.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 09:03 ET (13:03 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Barron's Online: Where The Earnings Growth Is
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   With another earnings season about to kick off, health care, technology, heavy industry and even the fickle energy sector could be Corporate America's pennant winners.   Energy companies, in particular, could hit a home run off rising oil prices and low expectations for the second quarter. And that could boost their shares. "The rationale here is that earnings growth leads stock prices," says Michael Thompson, director of research at Thomson Financial. "Stock prices reflect good earnings, and these are places where you will find it." If that's true, some financial stocks might be best left on the bench, next to home builders, auto makers and some retailers.   For the second consecutive quarter, the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 are expected to vault a sharply lowered bar. Analysts say corporate profits could grow 4.3% in the second quarter and 6.3% in the third, compared with year-earlier showings. For all of 2007, the black ink could rise by 7.8%. These estimates are much stronger than in April, when analysts feared that many companies would cut guidance amid worry about the U.S. economy.   In the past two weeks, several companies have reported financial results that beat expectations, including Walgreen (ticker: WAG), Oracle (ORCL) and Jabil Circuit (JBL).   True, there have been plenty of disappointments. FedEx (FDX) fell short, as did electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY), which also lowered guidance. Coffee-chain Starbucks (SBUX) said it would have a tough time hitting the upper end of its full-year guidance.   And earlier in June, investment banks Goldman Sachs (GS) and Bear Stearns (BSC) said that fiscal second-quarter profits had been squeezed by the nation's mounting home-loan defaults. Yet Standard & Poor's Equity Research Services chief investment strategist Sam Stovall says: "There hasn't been any drastic last-minute resetting of the bar by companies and analysts. Nothing has compelled analysts to curb expectations."   Profits generated by energy outfits in the second quarter are expected to be up 2%, versus a previous projection of a 9% decline, Thomson Financial says. The sector faces tough comparisons to 2006, when earnings jumped 24.7%.   But Jack Ablin, the chief investment officer for Harris Private Bank, says that energy-sector profits this year could be 10% above expectations. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial now see a 3% gain for the companies this year; in April, they were predicting a 5% drop.   "Estimates for earnings have been creeping up, and these are companies that make sure that sell-side analysts do not overshoot," says Doug Roman, director of equity management at PNC Financial Services. "If they are managing estimates up, that's a very good sign."   The financial sector, however, will be a mixed bag. Insurers and brokerages should fare well. Profits at Morgan Stanley (MS) jumped 40% in the second quarter, fueled by revenue from stock trading and investment banking. But the problems of Bear Stearns' hedge funds have left a cloud over other investment banks. And growing credit woes and rising interest rates don't bode well for commercial banks, says Brian Belski, the U.S. sector strategist for Merrill Lynch.   With profits growing 14%, the industrial sector is likely to provide the biggest boost to second-quarter profits, with technology in second place at 9%. The industrial group is eclectic and includes aerospace, machinery and construction-equipment companies that generate large portions of their revenue outside the U.S.   The industrial sector has been one of the most stable in the S&P 500, with projected profit growth remaining largely unchanged. "The economy is much stronger than people anticipated," says PNC's Roman. "And large multinational companies such as Boeing [BA], Goodrich [GR] and Precision Castparts [PCP] are also driving earnings."   Projections for technology companies have gradually fallen since the start of the year, in part due to disappointing forecasts from computer-chip makers.   But with full-year profits expected to rise 14%, tech could surpass all other S&P 500 sectors in '07, fueled partly by share repurchases. "It is no longer a stigma for a tech company to repurchase stock or pay a dividend," says Mark Demos, a portfolio manager with Fifth Third Asset Management.   Health care, meanwhile, could tie with industrials for second place in 2007. The sector enjoyed a 7.8% gain in 2006 and should see a 12% bounce this year, as pharmaceutical pipelines improve. Second-quarter profits could jump 7%, Thomson Financial predicts.   In sum, trading now at 15.6 times forward earnings, the S&P 500 does look pricey, compared with its expected long-term profit-growth rate of 8%.   But earnings comparisons look a lot better for almost every sector in 2007. And earnings at companies in the industrial, technology and health-care groups are growing strongly enough to keep their stock prices rising respectably in the coming 12 months.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Australia's Coles Board Weighs Takeover Bids
Story: MELBOURNE (Dow Jones)--Australian retailer Coles Group Ltd. (CGJ.AU) Saturday began deliberations on takeover bids, but the exit of a TPG Inc.-led consortium this week could take the edge off a potential A$20 billion price tag.   Local conglomerate Wesfarmers Ltd. (WES.AU) and its private equity partners are in the box seat to secure Coles after the TPG group walked away, blaming the state of the U.S. credit market for its decision.   The withdrawal of the TPG consortium was a major blow to Coles' chances of generating a competitive auction.   Woolworths Ltd. (WOW.AU), Coles' main rival, was also expected to have made an offer by the deadline of 9 a.m. Saturday (2300 GMT Friday), but only for parts of the business. Woolworths couldn't be reached for comment.   Competition rules would prevent Woolworths from bidding for Coles' core food and liquor assets, with the two companies controlling around 70% of Australia's supermarket industry.   "The board has received and commenced its consideration of proposals relating to the ownership of the company," a Coles spokesman said.   A Wesfarmers spokesman confirmed it had submitted a bid for the whole company.   If it succeeds, the takeover would be the biggest in Australia's history.   Wesfarmers, which is bidding with Europe's Permira, local private equity firm Pacific Equity Partners and Australia's Macquarie Bank Ltd. (MBL.AU), made an indicative A$19.7 billion offer in April after securing a 12.8% stake in the retailer.   But the consortium's bid price isn't constrained by its initial A$16.47 a share proposal. A person close to the consortium Friday said the offer could be pitched around A$16.00, given the deterioration in the business.   Coles shares closed Friday at A$16.12 - down 2 cents. The stock has fallen more than 4% in the past few weeks amid concerns the TPG consortium was poised to abandon its bid. Three of its original members, including Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts & Co., pulled out last month.   Wesfarmers shares soared to a record close Friday at A$45.73as investors backed its chances of winning control of Coles. The Perth-based company is expected to make a cash and scrip offer.   If Wesfarmers' bid falls short of the board's expectations, Coles maintains it could recapitalize its core food and liquor business with TPG and sell off its non-food assets, Officeworks and Target, a person close to Coles has said.   Woolworths is expected to lodge a bid for Officeworks, and either of the discount department stores Target or Kmart. The two Australian chains Target and Kmart are fully owned by Coles, and aren't part of the U.S. chains. Analysts expect Woolworths' ability to extract synergies through its own retail businesses will see it lodge a robust bid.   But the likelihood of an alternative deal with TPG emerging is slim, two people familiar with the situation have said. Analysts say such an option would also be drawn out; putting further pressure on the performance of Coles' businesses.    TPG's consortium includes Carlyle Group LP and Blackstone Group (BX). KKR, CVC and Bain Capital withdrew last month after conducting two weeks of due diligence.   The private equity group had pursued Coles for almost a year, initially approaching the retailer in August 2006.   Coles rejected two buyout proposals from the group and embarked on its own turnaround strategy instead.   But just four months later the business was formally put up for sale after profit downgrade due to deteriorating sales at its supermarkets.   Deutsche Bank AG and Carnegie Wylie & Co. are advising Coles.     -By Susan Murdoch, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4393; susan.murdoch@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 03:02 ET (07:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China's Nanjing Auto,Italy's Fiat To Add CNY3B To JV -Report
Story: SHANGHAI (AP)--China's Nanjing Auto and Italy's Fiat SpA have agreed to invest an additional CNY3 billion (US$400 million) in their troubled joint venture Nanjing Fiat, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Sunday.   According to earlier reports. Fiat was considering ending its partnership with Nanjing Auto because the Chinese side had delayed planned investments in the joint venture.   The two sides also reportedly were at odds over a potential tie-up between Fiat and rival Chinese automaker Chery Automobile.   "With the help of the government departments in Jiangsu Province, the two companies became reconciled," the Xinhua report said, citing the Shanghai Securities News.   It said that Nanjing Auto would have to rely on bank loans to make the investment in the Fiat venture because its financial resources were concentrated on resuscitating the U.K.'s MG Rover Group, which it acquired in 2005.   Staff at Nanjing Auto were not available for comment early Sunday. The report said that Fiat would begin production of its D200 in Nanjing.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 21:45 ET (01:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) A Fresh Eye On China Stocks -- And Strip Clubs
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Interview With Peter Siris   Managing Partner, Guerrilla Capital Management     The outspoken Peter Siris brings a fresh approach to one of the hottest investment topics: China, which accounts for about 20% of the $45 million Guerrilla Partners fund. The Manhattan-based fund invests in China through a little-known group of Chinese companies that are listed in the U.S. and Canada. Shares of these fast-growing companies trade for about 10 times earnings, a fraction of the multiples in the Shanghai market. Siris, a former top-ranked retailing analyst,also brings his smarts to that sector. He likes a group of auto dealers, and is down on some high-flying restaurant chains. He is also is partial to a pair of strip-club operators. Since Guerrilla was founded in 2000, the fund has returned 15.6% annually. So far this year, it's up 15.9%. The 62-year-old Siris also runs a separate fund for Chinese investments.   Siris' investments can be risky. Barron's has interviewed him six times, most recently in 2004. One of his favorites then, a pet insurer, has fallen more than 90%. Another pick, Bon-Ton Stores, a department-store chain that he still favors, has nearly tripled. An orthodox stockpicker, Siris is not.     Barron's: Peter, What's your approach?   Siris: Our strategy is very simple. We're just stockpickers. We look to buy undervalued, under-followed stocks and short overvalued and over-hyped stocks. I will tell you that we haven't made any money in shorts. It's funny. I go around and talk to a lot of my friends who run hedge funds. Nobody is making money in shorts any- more. This hasn't been a good market for shorts, but we short stocks because we like to limit risk and because at some point the valuations will come back.     Q: Why isn't your fund any larger?   A: We've never marketed Guerrilla. Last week was the first time we marketed anything to institutions, and it was Hua-Mei Partners, our China fund, not Guerrilla.     Q: Tell us about your China investment strategy.   A: What we do in China is invest in U.S.- and Canadian-listed companies. It gets confusing sometimes. In China, there is the Shanghai exchange. Then there is the Hong Kong exchange. There's a big waiting list for companies to go public on these exchanges. Even now, for every company that goes public there are probably a hundred in the queue, and a lot of companies want money sooner rather than later. What some of them do is reverse mergers into shells of U.S. companies. So you have a company, and I'm just making up names, that once was New Mexico Silver and stopped doing business. All of a sudden, it merges with China Hospital and its name gets changed to China Hospital.     Q: What's appealing about them?   A: They report earnings in English, follow GAAP accounting [generally accepted accounting principles] and are SEC-compliant. While H shares in Shanghai are selling at 40 or 50 times earnings, these companies, which are growing 40% to 80% per year, are much cheaper. The average multiple now of the companies in our fund is about eight times next year's earnings.     Q: Why are they so inexpensive?   A: First, local investors in China can't buy. It's very complicated for a Chinese investor to invest here. Most Americans don't know about them. You can go to Best Buy and see the stores. You can't go to China 3C and see its stores. And in a few cases, management doesn't speak English. There's a lack of good information. A lot of these companies have no real analyst coverage.     Q: How large are they?   A: We own some that are small with market caps of $80 or $100 million and some of them have market caps in the billions.     Q: Really?   A: One of my favorite Chinese expressions translates to "hang a lamb's head but sell dog meat," which means for a butcher to advertise lamb but sell dog meat. The problem with Americans is that they can't tell which companies are lambs and which are dogs.     Q: What's your edge?   A: I speak Mandarin. I started coming to China 34 years ago during the Cultural Revolution. I even wrote a bestselling novel about China in 1982 called The Peking Mandate. The change in China is unlike anything I've ever seen. Here's a country where for 10 years every school was closed. Anybody who had a dime more than anybody else got purged or was sent to Mongolia. And the people now are just on fire. I can be sitting here at 2 in the afternoon, which is 2 in the morning China time, and be getting e-mails from Chinese CEOs asking me questions. So what's going on there is pretty exceptional.     Q: Talk about some of the companies.   A: Take China 3C, a consumer-electronics retailer. Last year, sales rose five-fold. In the first quarter they did $85 million in revenues versus $13 million a year earlier.     Q: This is like a Best Buy in China?   A: Yes, China 3C [ticker: CHCG] operates leased departments in places like Wal-Mart and Carrefour. It had 913 stores at the end of the first quarter. It turned its inventory 50 times 50 times in the first quarter. If a U.S. retailer turns its inventory five times, it's thrilled. The company should earn about 55 cents a share this year, probably 80 cents next year. The stock is at 6 1/2. And it's the leading electronics retailer in China -- a market that is growing very fast. I don't know what you pay for that kind of growth, but it should be more than 11 times earnings. The market cap is around $300 million.     Q: What else do you like?   A: China Security & Surveillance Technology [CSCT]. This company is the leading player in the surveillance business in China. It's rolling up the surveillance market. All of a sudden the government wants more surveillance in the country. There's a law that mandates surveillance at every nightclub, every Internet cafe and every bar.   More important, there is a new law requiring every reasonably sized city to install surveillance equipment on every street. Sales and earnings have been doubling every year. The company should make $1.05 a share this year and $1.50 in 2008. The stock is about 14. Citadel [the big hedge-fund operator] has invested $110 million in the company. It's got superb management.     Q: You mention earnings estimates. Whose projections are you using?   A: Mine. In some cases, there are no analysts covering these companies.     Q: Give us one more Chinese stock.   A: How about General Steel [GSHO]? It has a great story. The company was founded by some farmers as the first privately owned steel company in China. It scavenged equipment that was being thrown away by a local government steel mill. Deng Xiaoping came and blessed it. It recently announced joint ventures with two big Chinese steel companies. General Steel should make about 40 cents a share this year, and next year as these joint ventures start to hit, it should make $1.50, with over $2 the year after. The stock is at 3.75. Eventually mainline analysts are going to pick up coverage of these companies because they're real businesses with exciting growth stories.     Q: You've followed retailing your entire career. Where do you see opportunities now?   A: In retailing, most people look at the demand side. I always focus on the supply side. Look at casual-dining restaurant companies like P.F. Chang [PFCB], Cheesecake Factory [CAKE], Red Robin Gourmet [RRGB], Buffalo Wild Wings [BWLD] and California Pizza Kitchen [CPKI]. They're growing 15% to 40% per year and generally have P/E multiples of 20 to 30. By my calculation, based on the rate they are opening restaurants, Americans are going to have to eat 28 meals a week out of the house by 2011 to justify these multiples. So unless Americans are going to get very fat or very rich or their houses are going to burn down, that's unlikely to happen.     Q: What attracts you in retailing?   A: We like the areas where supply is either contracting or there's consolidation. We like the auto dealers a lot. People say auto sales are going to go down, but dealers make their money on service. The more complex cars get, the more people take their cars to the dealer. The other interesting thing that is going to happen is that General Motors [GM], Ford [F] and Cerberus, or whatever Chrysler is called these days, are going to have to reduce the number of dealers. Here are some interesting numbers on annual unit sales per dealer: Toyota, 1,800. Honda, 1,300. Lexus, 1,500. BMW, 800. Mercedes, 700. OK? GM, 300. Chrysler, 300. Ford, 380. The average Toyota dealer sells six cars for every car the average GM dealer sells. What that means is a lot of GM, Ford and Chrysler dealers are losing money. The major U.S. auto manufacturers have got to reduce the number of dealers. So if you're looking over the next five years, you could see the number of dealers contract by a reasonable amount.     Q: What stocks do you own?   A: We own a few of them. Sonic is at 29 and should earn about $2.87 next year. United Auto Group is run by Roger Penske, who is a genius. It has invested a huge amount of money in the dealerships, which has hurt returns. The stock is at 21. It should make $1.50 this year, $1.75 next year. It has a lot of dealerships internationally and it will be selling the Smart car next year. [This week the company is changing its name to Penske Automotive Group (PAG).]     Q: What else attracts you in retailing?   A: Another area where competition is going away, interestingly, is department stores. After Federated bought May, it has been Macyizing the company.     Q: That's what Federated is called now.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) A Fresh Eye On China Stocks -- And -2-
Story: A: Yes, it's Macy's with a ticker M. A lot of the Federated stores have been turned into Macy's. From an operating standpoint, that's a smart decision. Everything is rebranded and everything is now homogenized. There are two problems with that. First, in Macyizing everything, management has left a significant vacuum at the high end. When you had the old Federated and May Co., there were always a few stores that had really upscale merchandise because they were in places like Beverly Hills. As Macy's has Macyized everything, it cut out that upscale business and Nordstrom [JWN] has picked it up. Macy's has left a void.     Q: Any other beneficiaries of the Macyizing?   A: Bon-Ton Stores [BONT]. Not many people have heard of Bon-Ton, but it's the anti-Macy's, because it has kept the local names on its department stores. Bon-Ton first merged with Elder-Beerman and then bought Saks' department-stores business. Bon-Ton has kept the local names and the local merchandising in each of its markets for stores like Younkers, Herberger's and Carson Pirie Scott. So while Macy's has turned Marshall Field's into Macy's, Bon-Ton has left Carson Pirie Scott alone.     Q: Isn't Bon-Ton like a public LBO?   A: Yes. It took on a billion dollars of debt to buy the Saks business. It's a highly leveraged company. But it's paying down the debt. Bon-Ton has tremendous operating leverage and very significant operating efficiencies. Bon-Ton should make $3.25 a share this year and $4.65 next year. The stock is around 40. We think Bon-Ton has $8 a share in earnings power looking out two or three years.     Q: How about the strip club business? What attracts you to it?   A: Let me say that I've never visited a gentlemen's club. It's not my idea of how to spend an evening. But I recognize a good business when I see it.     Q: We're not sure if we believe you about visiting the clubs, but go on.   A: First, they have 90% gross margins. If you go into a gentlemen's club, they charge you a cover and a lot of money for drinks. Secondly, the girls who work there, the dancers, or what the industry calls the "talent," pay $150 to $200 a shift for the privilege of working. It's my kind of business where you charge both customers and employees to walk in the door.     Q: The dancers presumably make enough money in tips to offset the fee they pay?   A: They make money in tips. Or they can be like Anna Nicole Smith, who started out working at Rick's Cabaret. That's where she met Howard Marshall, the billionaire she married. I asked one guy in the business, "What's the biggest risk to your business model?" He said if the government stops immigration from Eastern Europe. These companies net 35% to 40% pre-tax, after all their expenses. There are huge barriers to entry. Why? Because most people don't want them in their neighborhoods. There are big zoning restrictions. These companies can make acquisitions at three to five times earnings. Why? Because there aren't a lot of buyers. The church isn't going to buy one. We may laugh about it, but flash back 20 or 30 years ago, and people might have reacted the same way to an investment in a casino company. Now the funds that won't buy an MGM Mirage are few and far between.     Q: How do you play this sector?   A: There are two public companies that we like a lot. One is VCG Holding, ticker PTT, and the other is Rick's Cabaret, ticker RICK. This is a real business, one that takes management, where you can develop a national brand and have VIP cards that you can use in city after city. And the two leading companies in the industry have just a 1% market share.     Q: Is the strategy at Rick's and VCG to roll up a fragmented industry at attractive prices?   A: Yes. When you mention this industry to people, their first reaction is to smile and then they say, "Gee, I didn't even know there were public companies." These companies need capital to grow. That's the good news and the bad news. The cash flow is huge because this is a very profitable business. So the rate that they can grow depends on their access to the capital markets. Having said that, Rick's could earn 48 cents this year. It's on a September fiscal year. And it could make 85 cents next year. The stock is trading about $9.50 a share.     Q: How about VCG?   A: It should make 58 cents a share this year and 90 cents next year, and the stock is trading at about $8. Rick's has a very good brand name. VCG has a little deeper management team. Rick's has the Rick's brand and it also has the Club Onyx brand targeted at African-American men. PTT has a bunch of different brands.     Q: People might worry about mob influence after watching The Sopranos. Is that a problem?   A: No. What you really have to look at in this business is management. VCG's president, Michael Ocello, is on the school board of a town near St. Louis. When he ran for the school board, his opponent said, "You run a strip club." Ocello still won. The reality is these are well-managed public companies that have to follow all the rules, and they've walked away from business that they thought was dicey. People used to ask about mob influence in the trash business. That didn't stop Waste Management from making it a real business. People used to worry about mob influence in  gambling. That didn't stop Steve Wynn from getting rich. When these companies come around to talk to investors, you get a lot of the hedge-fund managers who want to hear their story.     Q: Let's end it on that note. Thanks, Peter.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:10 ET (04:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE:Taiwan Union Insur To Sell 75% To Want Want Chmn Fund
Story: (Updates with comments from Union Insurance official and adds details throughout)     By Joy C. Shaw   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     TAIPEI (Dow Jones)--The board of Taiwan's Union Insurance Co. (2816.TW) on Friday agreed to sell a 75% stake for NT$1.5 billion (US$45.8 million) to an investment fund led by Tsai Eng Meng, the chairman of Want Want Holdings Ltd. (W08.SG), the insurer said in a filing to the Taiwan Stock Exchange late Friday.   The company had hoped to sell a controlling stake to a consortium led by Newbridge Capital, but the private equity fund's final offer was less attractive than Tsai's, said Kenny Ching, Union Insurance's deputy spokesman.   The fund led by Tsai will buy 150 million of Union Insurance's newly issued shares through a private placement at NT$10 each, the insurer said.    The transaction will close by mid-August, when Tsai will have the right to appoint a management team and to decide whether there should be further fundraising, Ching said.   Union Insurance, Taiwan's fourth-largest non-life insurer by market, suffered losses last year mainly because of loan defaults by companies of the Rebar Group. Union Insurance is also part of the Rebar Group.   The property insurer posted a net loss of NT$2.79 billion last year, according to a filing to the Taiwan Stock Exchange.   Earlier this year, Union Insurance said it plans to issue up to 350 million new shares through a private placement and was targeting specific strategic investors.   The insurer in January signed a memorandum of understanding to sell around US$100 million worth of new shares to a consortium led by Newbridge Capital, a unit of Texas Pacific Group. Swiss Reinsurance Co. was also in the consortium, Ching said.   While the Newbridge Capital consortium offered to buy the stake at the same price, it also requires other financial terms which makes its offer less attractive, Ching said. He declined to specify the Newbridge consortium's offer, but said it involves Union Insurance's existing debt.    "Newbridge Capital will no longer be a controlling shareholder," Ching said. "But we don't rule out if they also want to make other investments in the company."     -By Joy C. Shaw, Dow Jones Newswires; (8862) 2502-2557; joy.shaw@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 03:17 ET (07:17 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Current Yield: What Makes The Bond Bulls Jump
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   Ben Bernanke got bond bulls' boxers in a bunch last week, after the Federal Reserve he heads indicated no easing of interest rates for the foreseeable future, despite moderating inflation.   But like the eternal optimist in Voltaire's Candide, Dr. Pangloss, bulls jumped on Friday's Commerce Department report -- which showed that the rate of gain in its personal-consumption expenditures index (excluding food and energy) fell from 2% in April to 1.9% in May -- as a buy signal. That was just below the Fed's unofficial comfort zone of 1% to 2% for the first time in three years.   The yield on ten-year Treasuries ended Friday at 4.87%, down from 5.13% the prior week, while two-year yields slid to 4.87% from 4.92%. Big Ben, the market seemed to be saying, you're on the clock.   The housing recession and the related subprime-mortgage mess have forced Bear Stearns to embark on a bailout that could cost as much as $3.2 billion for one of its two troubled hedge funds. The nervousness is so palpable that the high-flying, high-yield, new-issue market virtually shut down last week, as a $3.6 billion financing planned by two private-equity firms buying out U.S. Foodservice was given the thumbs down by junk-bond investors.   "The real economy" is more worried about the sinking housing sector than core inflation, according to John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's. As the year began ("Conflicting Crystal Balls," Jan. 1), he correctly predicted that the Fed would keep rates steady in the first half, as it has since mid-2006, following 17 rate hikes in a row. As the table on this page shows, he's offering  the same forecast for the second half. However, he says,  "The likelihood of a [rate] cut is greater than a hike, despite the Fed's focus on inflation."   Lonski's opinion on 2007 is shared by a majority -- seven out of 10 -- of our forecasters. Two participants see a 25-basis-point, or quarter-percentage-point, cut by year-end, while one expects a half-point reduction. Their outlooks for 10-year Treasury yields range from 4.80% to 5.50%.   That yield "should be 50-to-75 basis points higher now," says Andrew Stenwall, head of Nuveen Investments' taxable fixed-income group, because there's still too much liquidity in the market. He sees "no contagion" in financial markets from the subprime mortgage debacle, "minimal" risk of a recession, and believes the Fed has only been able to keep rates steady because of the housing slump.   But Thomas di Galoma, head of U.S. Treasury trading at Jefferies & Co., says "the Fed will have to get in front" of a deteriorating housing sector at some point and cut rates twice, by a total of 50 basis points, by the end of the year. Kevin Giddis, managing director of fixed income at Morgan Keegan, foresees just one 25-basis-point cut later in 2007. The continuing decline in housing and the subprime-mortgage meltdown "won't be swept under the rug," he says.   Yet Colin Lundgren, head of institutional fixed income at RiverSource Institutional Investors, believes "the housing market is in the process of bottoming out." And the submerged subprime-mortgage sector is "more of a portfolio event than an economic event" that will remain contained. That's why he expects the Fed to continue to stay its hand.   Two of the group, including Jim McDonald, who manages money-market funds at T. Rowe Price, expects the Fed to stand pat for now but see a rate hike in 2008. "If [the Fed] is concerned about inflation, so am I," he says.   All agree that low unemployment supports the Fed's current stance. So Friday's jobs report could potentially produce more fireworks than the Fourth of July.   ---   E-mail: tom.sullivan@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Plugged In: Salesforce Vs. Oracle, Part 2
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Where's the beef?   That was Salesforce.com Chief Executive Marc Benioff's question for me minutes after Oracle's quarterly earnings call last week. It was in response to my feature story ("A Tough Sell," June 25) predicting that Oracle would announce a contract win against Salesforce (ticker: CRM) in on-demand customer-relationship management, or CRM, services.   In an e-mail, Benioff asked: "Where's the beef? Where's the beachhead?" referring to a quote in the story that claimed Oracle (ORCL) was preparing to go after Salesforce's biggest corporate customers. To emphasize -- which Benioff is wont to do -- the CEO e-mailed me a video link of the hamburger ad that spawned the now-famous phrase. That,  I admit, was a nice touch.   So here's the beef. During the earnings call, Oracle President Charles Phillips announced several deals for his company's latest software-as-a-service, Oracle On Demand. Phillips revealed "key wins" from Fidelity Investments, ConocoPhillips (COP), Motorola (MOT) and Automatic Data Processing (ADP). That last one is a Salesforce customer.   "ADP? We have 8,000 users at ADP," Benioff crowed. "How many does Oracle have? ADP has 50,000 employees. I am sure someone, somewhere at the company could have" Oracle On Demand.   Oracle didn't disclose how many on-demand users it has, but the world's largest business-software company just relaunched its upgraded service in April. During the quarter, revenue recognized from On Demand was up 74% from the  year-earlier level. "Bookings were even stronger," Phillips added.   So assume Oracle's beachhead is tiny. But it's the launching point for a possible war. And if Oracle's ability to sell its on-demand service to an existing Salesforce customer is so benign, why is Benioff worked into a lather?   "Just saying ADP is a customer is not interesting," Benioff said. "It has a huge Oracle implementation there. We want to know the details."   Adding insult to injury, not only is ADP using Oracle On Demand, the Illinois-based payment processor is expected to become a reseller of NetSuite, another provider of on-demand business applications. NetSuite offers the entire enterprise-resource planning platform -- such as accounting, manufacturing and supply-chain applications -- as a service over the Internet to small and medium-sized companies.   NetSuite isn't a direct competitor with Salesforce.com -- yet. But it is a privately held start-up that's majority-owned by Benioff's rival and former boss, Oracle CEO Larry Ellison. The company is expected to file for an initial offering in the very near future -- perhaps as early as this week. It is anticipated to be one of the year's hottest IPOs. A NetSuite spokeswoman wouldn't comment on ADP or a potential  offering.   During the earnings call, Phillips went on to say that enterprise customers are finding that Oracle On Demand's Internet interface is "comparable" to that of Salesforce. The previous superiority of Salesforce's product is "not going to drive deals anymore," Phillips asserted.   If he's right,  Salesforce's strategy of going after big corporate customers is going to meet some serious resistance -- especially in pricing. Oracle can bundle its On-Demand product with traditional CRM software.   Said Phillips: "We're taking this very seriously, and we have momentum."   Care for some cheese on that burger, Mr. Benioff?   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) iPhone Will Draw Power From RIM, Palm Shares
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tiernan Ray   The reviews are in, and Apple's first cellular phone, the iPhone, is being saluted as a groundbreaking consumer product with enormous commercial potential.   That could be great for Apple, but what's it mean for Research in Motion (ticker: RIMM), maker of the ubiquitous BlackBerry, and Palm (PALM), producer of the Treo smart phone, arguably the leaders in data-oriented wireless gadgets?   It means their stocks will likely struggle for awhile.   Whether or not the iPhone sells 10 million units by the end of 2008, as Apple Chief Exec Steve Jobs has forecast, the gadget has convinced some observers that consumers increasingly will use cellphones to browse the Web for information, listen to music and watch videos.   It won't be easy for Research in Motion and Palm to prove they can dominate this new landscape the way they have their existing markets for corporate wireless e-mail and personal organizers, respectively.   At the moment, both stocks seem priced for continued prosperity that may be elusive. Following last Thursday's consensus-busting quarterly earnings of $1.17 a share, RIM shares sport a multiple of 34.5 times its next four quarters' earnings, and Palm, despite its report of a 43% drop in quarterly net income, still trades at 30.8 times, ahead of the 21 average for Motorola (MOT), Nokia (NOK), Ericsson (ERIC) and Qualcomm (QCOM).   Those healthy valuations are based on their expected success selling BlackBerries and Treos to traditional customers, while the real challenge will be adapting to a future providing information and delivering multimedia experiences, areas where neither company has an established hold.   RIM's grip on the market for business users, with about 9.6 million subscribers, insulates it for now from Apple, whose phone is expected to appeal to retail consumers.   But RIM is already carrying the battle beyond its BlackBerry franchise by selling gadgets to the masses: Its most recent offerings, the Pearl and the Curve, have added cameras and music playback to RIM's forte of corporate e-mail.   Not everyone's convinced RIM can broaden its market.   "The share price is assuming a significant success in the consumer market outside of mobile e-mail that we are still not seeing," says Richard Windsor, an analyst with Nomura Securities in London who has the lone Sell rating on RIM stock. "Upside is still being driven by small and medium enterprises."   The shares' fair value is just $138, claims Windsor, based on discounted-cash-flow estimates and comparable price-to-earnings multiples.   RIM has yet to prove it can do well at the new things for which Apple is being praised. The Web browser is awful on the BlackBerry Pearl, in Windsor's opinion, while RIM's devices that emphasize music playback have yet to sell in large volumes outside the business market.   It's still possible that RIM will deliver the goods: The company has the best radio engineers in the world, according to Peter Misek, an analyst with Canaccord Adams. RIM, he says, has the opportunity to strike alliances with content providers that could give its music and video abilities a boost.   "RIM is going to become a content platform," says Misek, who Friday raised his price target on the stock from $225 to $275. Multimedia can expand RIM's potential market from 100 million global mobile e-mail users to 400 million consumers of music- and video-enabled smart phones.   But that long-term potential presumes RIM does as well or better with multimedia than bigger phone makers. These companies -- principally Nokia, Motorola and Ericsson --  already are incorporating e-mail capabilities similar to RIM's.   It's not impossible for RIM to adapt, but its rich valuation leaves little room for error.   Shorting RIM stock during its 145% rise over the past 12 months was not a great idea. That's why Fred Hickey, editor of The High-Tech Strategist newsletter and Barron's Roundtable member, is buying puts on RIM: It's a cheaper way to play the downside as RIM wades into the unpredictable waters iPhone is charting.   Palm faces more serious challenges because its Treo line of phones has changed little in recent years even as Apple geared up to offer better e-mail and Web browsing, with music to boot.   How badly the company's products have stagnated was clear from the tepid response to its recent release of Foleo, a kind of small laptop computer.   And Palm's Treos are squarely in Apple's sights.   "Palm appeals to more or less the same group as Apple --  young people in their 20s and 30s, and owners of small businesses," says Lawrence Harris, who follows Palm for Oppenheimer and rates its shares Market Perform.   AT&T (T) has been slashing the prices of the Treo 680 by as much as 50% in the past month, observes Harris. Not a good sign on the eve of AT&T rolling out Apple's iPhone.   Palm's lack of direction prompted a recapitalization last month by private-equity firm Elevation Partners, which is plowing in $325 million of cash and adding $400 million of debt. The recap means a sweet $9 a share dividend, which may be an opportunity for investors to consolidate some of Palm's 15% rise this year and head for the exits.   To be sure, RIM and Palm's loyal audiences make both companies contenders in wireless information consumption. But the rich multiples on their stocks presume they've got the future figured out. With reviewers touting the innovations of newcomer Apple, both companies may have to go back to the drawing board. Investors don't have to join them.   ---   A version of this story appeared June 28 on Barron's Online.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China Official:Former Bank Regulator Is Everbright Grp Chmn
Story: SHANGHAI (Dow Jones)--China has named a former banking regulator, Tang Shuangning, to be chairman of China Everbright Group, the parent of China Everbright Bank Co., a senior regulatory official said Saturday.   The appointment of the former vice chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission is a step toward the reorganization of the State Council-controlled conglomerate as China Everbright Bank awaits a capital injection from the government.   Jiang Dingzhi, vice chairman and deputy party secretary of the CBRC, also said that the reform of Agricultural Bank of China is still under study.   He said a government audit of Agricultural Bank of China's books is still ongoing. That audit is viewed by analysts as an important step in establishing how much money the government should inject into Agricultural Bank of China to recapitalize it.   -By Rick Carew and Rose Yu, Dow Jones Newswires; 8621 6120-1200; rick.carew@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:49 ET (04:49 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Citibank Japan To Start Selling Fund Of Funds - Nikkei
Story: NEW YORK (Nikkei)--Citibank Japan Ltd. will start selling through its nationwide branch network on Monday a fund of funds-style investment trust targeting individuals, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition.   On Sunday, Citibank Japan will be converted into a Japanese subsidiary of Citibank NA with a local banking license, from a Japanese branch of the U.S. bank, which held the license.   The fund of funds is the first product created through the bank's collaboration with Nikko Cordial Corp. (8603.TO), which recently became a securities unit of Citigroup Inc. (C).   The product has a diversified global portfolio in four asset categories - stocks, bonds, real estate and hedge funds.   Nikko AM International Inc., an affiliate of Nikko Asset Management, will be responsible for determining how to distribute investment capital among the more than 10 funds it selects for their high-yield potential.   "We will invest in a broad range of assets from safe instruments to (risky ones) in emerging countries and commodity markets," a fund manager at Nikko AM said.   According to Citibank Japan, many of its customers are individuals who open accounts at the bank for investment purposes while maintaining accounts at domestic banks for settlement purposes.  To meet their needs, the bank has marketed to them nearly 90 mutual funds and foreign currency-denominated vehicles.   Citibank Japan intends to introduce the new trust to mark its transformation into a Japanese bank.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 19:03 ET (23:03 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(7/2) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from June 21 through 27.   Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Sonesta International Hotels (SNSTA)   Mercury Real Estate Advisors wants Sonesta's independent directors to gauge whether the controlling family is interested in taking the company private. Mercury contends that Sonesta's "diminutive size, controlling family ownership and consequent share illiquidity make it ill-suited to be a publicly traded company." Mercury holds 347,442 shares (9.4% of the total outstanding).     HealthSpring (HS)   New York hedge fund Clinton Group wants HealthSpring to consider a recapitalization and a Dutch tender offer of $22-$23 per share for 30% of its stock. Clinton asserts that HealthSpring's stock, which recently closed at $18.20, is undervalued, especially considering that it is below the February 2006 initial public offering price of $19.50. Clinton Group holds 2,893,404 shares (5.05%).     1-800-Flowers.com (FLWS)   RLR Capital Partners plans to have discussions with the company regarding its business and prospects. RLR says it supports the initiatives undertaken by management and that it has been impressed by what it called the successful launch, highly profitable growth and market positioning of BloomNet, the company's wire service linking retail florists. RLR holds 1,307,000 shares (5.1%).     Gensym (GNSM)   Denmark's Gedda Holding has proposed buying software maker Gensym for $2.50 a share, but the company rejected the bid and said that it is open to proposals from other parties. Gedda Holding is an affiliate of Johan Magnusson Gedda, who owns 970,000 shares (13.12%).     Original Filings     Bel Fuse (BELFA)   Funds managed by Mario Gabelli's Gamco Investors (GBL) reported ownership of 147,800 shares (5.5%) after buying 134,300 from April 23 to June 22 at $34.17 to $40.06 per share.     Increases in Holdings     Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (KKD)   Mohamed Abdulmoshin Al Kharafi & Sons, the company's largest shareholder, increased its stake to 8,263,347 shares (12.76%) by buying 385,484. No further details were released.     Mace Security International (MACE)   A group including Ancora Capital raised its position to about 1.31 million shares (8.58%) from the 1.06 million reported on Nov. 30, 2006.     Station Casinos (STN)   UBS (UBS) increased its holdings to 3.29 million shares (5.74%) from the 3.2 million (5.5%) reported on May 25.     Decreases in Holdings     Exco Resources (XCO)   Billionaire T. Boone Pickens recently lowered his stake to 12.45 million shares (11.9%) by selling 375,000 on the open market. No other details of the transaction were reported.     TLC Vision (TLCV)   Glenhill Advisors cut its holdings to 6.8 million shares (9.8%) from the 9.61 million reported in March. Glenhill has decided to become a passive 13G investor.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/2) The Striking Price: iPhone Intro Incites Call-Selling
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   As plump and pluckable as perfect fruit on a tree, Apple sits atop the options market, reflecting the adulation of millions for the new iPhone.   In optionsland, which expresses excitement and fear via implied volatility, Apple's calls are among the most richly priced, based on anticipation that the Apple (ticker: AAPL) iPhone will be to cellphones what the iPod was to music. Naturally, such optimism is being met with skepticism (For more on Apple, see story page 15).   "If ever there was an opportunity to buy the rumor and sell the fact, this is it," one market-maker said. For the past week, in particular, institutional traders have sold Apple's calls just as surely as the market maker said individual investors "gunned up" Apple's options prices.   Indeed, Apple's implied volatility, along with financial stocks shaded by subprime-mortgage fears, is one of  the highest of all mega-cap stocks in the  options market; in the hardware and semiconductor sector, Apple's implied volatility is the highest. While many expect iPhone to catapult Apple's $120 stock into the stratosphere, institutional traders think the stock may actually stumble.   Of course, no one is really willing to actually bet against the iPhone. The stock is, after all, up about 44% year-to-date, 112% the past year, and 1,329% during the past five years, a difficult stretch for some institutional investors. Such investors are monetizing their view that everyone is too excited about the iPhone by selling richly-priced call options. This is the same type of elitist contrarian reasoning that traditionally paces trading, and often proves right. Volatility, like a rubber band, snaps when stretched too thin.   To wager against the iPhone crowd and not the iPhone, some traders are selling slightly out-of-the-money August calls and buying stock, which allows them to benefit from Apple's high implied volatility. Others traders are initiating "call spreads" to bet the stock trades in a range, or even declines, once the iPhone is released. Goldman Sachs, for example, advised clients to buy August 125 calls and sell August 135 calls. Apple's August expiration options capture the iPhone launch, and also Apple's July 25 earnings report, which should be another stock-moving event.   Some individual investors who own Apple stock, and are worried about preserving gains (many, perhaps, whose kids are excited about the iPhone) are buying puts, especially those with August expiration, as puts are as inexpensively priced as the calls are richly priced.   The ripple effect of the iPhone is also affecting trading in AT&T (T), iPhone's U.S. distributor. Bullish out-of-the-money call trading in July and August indicates some traders expect AT&T stock to rise. And bearish expectations are hurting Research in Motion (RIMM), which makes the Blackberry, and Palm (PALM), maker of the Treo (See related story, page 16). The iPhone could push RIMM and Palm lower, so selling some out-of-the-money calls, or buying puts, makes sense for those seeking to profit from the headline risk that will likely smack the stocks.   So the iPhone seems to offer something for everyone. The only question left to decide is if more investors take the call, or not.   ---   E-mail: steven.sears@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: MWB Appoints Bk Of America To Find Buyer For Hotels -Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Marylebone Warwick Balfour Group PLC (MWB.LN) has appointed advisers to sell its Malmaison and Hotel du Vin assets for more than GBP450 million, The Times said Saturday, citing Chief Executive Richard Balfour-Lynn.   After the sale of the assets to Vector Hospitality collapsed, MWB has appointed Bank of America Corp (BAC) to find a new buyer, Balfour-Lynn confirmed, according to the paper.   The hotels are expected to be acquired by a property investment firm on a sale and lease-back basis, with MWB continuing to manage them, the newspaper said.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9413     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 07:03 ET (11:03 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(7/2) Speaking Of Dividends: Kaiser Cleans Up Its Act
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Kaiser Aluminum re-emerged last July from four years under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. And on Wednesday, it flexed its financial muscles by reinstating its dividend. California-based Kaiser (ticker: KALU) will pay an initial quarterly of 18 cents a share Aug. 17 to investors on its books July 27. The stock goes ex-dividend July 25.   Declared CEO Jack A. Hockema, "With confidence in our financial strength, Kaiser's board is comfortable introducing a dividend while continuing to pursue significant investments in initiatives for the long-term growth of the company."   Traded on Nasdaq, the shares went from a 52-week low last August of 36.50 to a 52-week high May 10 of 89.24. Reflecting an uninspiring first quarter, they now change hands in the mid-70s. Kaiser was added to the Russell 2000 last week.   Once a far-flung enterprise of mining, refining and smelting operations, the company now has just 11 plants in North America, and one minority-owned smelter in the United Kingdom. With annual sales of $1.36 billion, it makes fabricated aluminum products, primarily for the aerospace, industrial and transportation markets. Maxxam (MXM), whose businesses include forest products, real estate and horse-racing, owns close to two-thirds of Kaiser's 20.6 million common shares.   Kaiser's Chapter 11 miseries resulted from the economic slowdown earlier this decade, weak aluminum prices and asbestos litigation. But with the aerospace, defense and general-engineering markets currently strong, it has ongoing contracts with companies like Boeing, Airbus and Lockheed Martin. "We're very optimistic that this cycle has good legs to it and will extend out for a few years," said Hockema. Accordingly, it's investing $139 million to double capacity at its mainstay Trentwood rolling mill near Spokane, Wash.   Kaiser could figure in the proposed purchase of Canada's Alcan (AL) by Alcoa (AA), if Alcoa has to shed some assets to win regulatory approval. "We have a lot of dry powder," Hockema said. "We see ourselves as well-positioned to be a buyer of assets that are attractive for our portfolio."   For the sixth time in three years, General Mills (GIS) is again sweetening its quarterly common dividend, to 39 cents a share from 37 cents. Investors of record July 10 will receive the new payout Aug. 1. Ex-date: July 6. Yield: 2.66%.   Including predecessors, the Minneapolis company has paid dividends without interruption or reduction since 1898. The Big Board-listed shares set a 52-week high of 61.52 on June 4, and trade just a few notches below that level currently.   Archrival Kellogg (K), trading near 52, pays a 31-cent quarterly and yields 2.40%.   A Big-G brand sampling includes Cheerios and Wheaties cereals; Gold Medal flour; Betty Crocker and Bisquick baking mixes; and Green Giant vegetables. Its 2001 acquisition of Pillsbury doubled its size. Grain costs have soared as demand for the alternative fuel ethanol, made from corn, grows -- so farmers have shifted to planting more corn at the expense of oats.   For its fiscal '07 year, ended May 31, General Mills earned $1.14 billion, or $3.18 a share, up from fiscal '06's $1.09 billion, or $2.90. Revenue rose 6%, to $12.44 billion. The company expects fiscal '08 profits to advance 7% to 8%, or to $3.39 to $3.43 a share.   The biggest U.S. consumer-electronics outfit, Best Buy, Wednesday announced a $5.5 billion stock buyback, representing one-fourth of its market value. With  $2.8 billion in cash, it also boosted its quarterly common dividend  30%, to 13 cents a share from a dime. The respective payment and record dates are Oct. 30 and Oct. 9; the ex-dividend date is Oct. 4. The Minnesota company paid its first dividend in 2003 and has enhanced it annually.   The shares (BBY) change hands in the mid-40s on the Big Board and now yield 1.11%. Standard & Poor's rates Best Buy a Strong Buy. The big retailer's 52-week high and low are 58.49 and 43.51.   Best Buy also increased its planned store count in the U.S. and Canada by 400 outlets, for a target of 1,800. The company also says it remains committed to expansion in China.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: INTERVIEW: ABN Amro Hopes For Stake In China's Huishang Bank
Story: SHANGHAI (Dow Jones)--Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding NV (ABN) hopes to take a strategic stake in Chinese regional lender Huishang Bank Co. and rapidly expand its own China network, ABN Amro Asia's chief executive said Saturday.   "We would be interested in starting a strategic relationship with Huishang Bank under terms and conditions that are acceptable on both sides," Jeroen Drost, chief executive of ABN Amro Asia told Dow Jones Newswires in an interview. "That would be something we are very interested in."   He said ABN Amro isn't targeting a specific stake size, but rather a mutually beneficial strategic partnership.   Huishang Bank was formed in late 2005 from the merger of Hefei City Commercial Bank and several smaller credit cooperatives in Anhui Province. Under current Chinese regulations, a single foreign investor is limited to holding no more than 20% of a local bank.   "From our perspective it has to be a strategic relationship," Drost said. "Just taking a stake from a financial perspective might be interesting, but I might as well speculate on the stock exchange then."   ABN Amro plans to add six outlets this year to its current 14-outlet mainland China network and another six to 10 next year "depending on how fast we can process the applications," said Linda Wong, country executive at ABN Amro in China.   The expansion plans by ABN Amro into China come as Barclays PLC (BCS) and a consortium led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS.LN) are competing to take control of ABN Amro.   "Asia is one of the most interesting parts in ABN Amro Bank and one of the reason why Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland are interested in ABN Amro Bank and going to pay a good price," Drost said.   Drost said he didn't expect the merger of the bank with either of the two bidders would impact ABN Amro's China business because neither bidder has a strong organic mainland China presence. Royal Bank of Scotland holds a strategic stake in Bank of China Ltd., one of China's Big Four state lenders.     -By Rick Carew, Dow Jones Newswires; 8621 6120-1200; rick.carew@dowjones.com   (Rose Yu contributed to this story.)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 06:53 ET (10:53 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Motorcar Parts of America, Inc. -2-
Story: Operating loss in fiscal 2007 was $2.5 million, compared to operating income of $6.3 million in fiscal 2006.  Operating expenses increased 24.3%, primarily due to the previously mentioned consulting fees incurred in connection with SOX compliance, FAS 123R stock compensation expenses, higher research and development expenses incurred in connection with the Mexico facility and severance costs.  Operating expenses for the full year also include restatement expenses and a reduction in expenses associated with the recording of a shareholder note receivable. Net loss was $5.0 million in fiscal 2007, or $0.59 per diluted share, compared to net income of $2.1 million, or $0.25 cents per diluted share, in fiscal 2006.        Non-GAAP Operating Results - Fiscal Year     Non-GAAP operating income in fiscal 2007 was $9.2 million, compared to non-GAAP operating income of $12.4 million in fiscal 2006.  Non-GAAP net income was $2.0 million, or $0.23 per diluted share, in fiscal 2007, compared to non-GAAP net income of $5.7 million, or $0.67 per diluted share, in fiscal 2006.        Financial Condition     As of March 31, 2007, the Company had cash and equivalents of $0.3 million, negative working capital of ($27.2) million and total assets of $132.0 million. Debt and capital lease obligations totaled $28.0 million and shareholders' equity stood at $47.8 million.  Cash flow used in operating activities totaled $9.3 million for the year ended March 31, 2007.     In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2007, we reclassified core inventory held at our locations and held at customers' locations to long-term core inventory. The reclassified core inventory totaled $42,492,000 and $33,822,000 at March 31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. This reclassification had no impact on total assets or core inventory value.     In May 2007, the Company raised $40.1 million of capital through a private placement.     "In fiscal 2007, we devoted significant resources toward achieving compliance with section 404 of Sarbanes-Oxley.  We completed this endeavor, and are now able to provide our shareholders with a greater level of confidence in our financial controls and procedures," said Mervyn McCulloch, MPA's Chief Financial Officer. "With net proceeds of approximately $36.5 million in additional capital, we have the resources needed to meet our working capital requirements and execute our current business strategies."        Business Outlook     "In fiscal 2008, we anticipate another year of strong revenue growth, along with a continued reduction of our operating costs.  We will also continue streamlining our distribution and logistics operations in an effort to lower our production costs even more," said Mr. Joffe.  "These initiatives should further improve our competitive position and allow MPA to further expand our market share.  We expect our quarterly operating results to continue to improve, with a significant increase in our operating margins by the end of this fiscal year."        Conference Call     MPA will host a conference call at 6:00 a.m. PT (9:00 a.m. ET) on Monday, July 2, 2007 to discuss results for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended March 31, 2007.  To participate in the conference call, please dial the following number five to ten minutes prior to the scheduled conference call time: (888) 482-0024. This conference call will be broadcast live over the Internet and can be accessed by all interested parties on the MPA website at www.motorcarparts.com.  To listen to the live call, please go to the MPA website at least fifteen minutes prior to the start of the call to register, download, and install any necessary audio software. For those unable to participate during the live broadcast, a replay will be available shortly after the call on MPA's website for 90 days.        Use of Non-GAAP Financial Measures     To supplement the Company's condensed consolidated financial statements presented on a GAAP basis, the Company is providing certain income statement information that is not calculated according to GAAP.  The Company believes that its non-GAAP disclosures are useful in evaluating its operating results as this information supplies the user with another view of the matching of costs and expenses.  A reconciliation of the adjustments to GAAP results for the three and twelve month periods ended March 31, 2007 and March 31, 2006 is included below.  The non-GAAP information presented is supplemental and is not purported to be a substitute for information prepared in accordance with GAAP.        About MPA     Motorcar Parts of America, Inc. is a leading remanufacturer of replacement alternators and starters for imported and domestic cars and light trucks in the United States and Canada. MPA has facilities in the United States in Torrance, California, and Nashville, Tennessee, as well as in Mexico, Singapore and Malaysia.  MPA's websites are located at www.motorcarparts.com and www.quality-built.com. condition of any of our major customers, the impact of high gasoline prices, the potential for changes in consumer spending, consumer preferences and general economic conditions, increased competition in the automotive parts industry, including increased competition from Chinese manufacturers, difficulty in obtaining cores and component parts or increases in the costs of those parts, political or economic instability in any of the foreign countries where we conduct operations, unforeseen increases in operating costs and other factors discussed herein and in the Company's filings with the SEC. Headline: Portugal BCP's Jardim Goncalves Could Fire CEO -Paper
Story: LISBON (Dow Jones)--Jorge Jardim Goncalves, the head of the supervisory board of Banco Comercial Portugues (BCP.LB), could fire the bank's chief executive, Paulo Teixeira Pinto, weekly Expresso reports without citing sources.   The supervisory board is holding an extraordinary meeting Monday to discuss a request from a group of shareholders representing more than 5% of the share capital to call a general meeting.   These shareholders were previously reported by local media as intending to give more power to Teixeira Pinto.   In May, the supervisory board of BCP faced opposition from shareholders and was forced to remove a proposal to change the bank's bylaws from the annual meeting's agenda.   Jardim Goncalves proposed giving the supervisory board the right to appoint the executive board and require a 75% majority of issued votes to change the company's bylaws, up from 66%, in order to make BCP a less-likely target for an unsolicited bid after its failed takeover attempt for smaller rival Banco BPI (BPI.LB) in early May.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.expresso.pt     -By Lisbon Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 351-21-319-1863     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 08:47 ET (12:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Thai PTT To Merge Rayong Refinery, Aromatics By Early 2008
Story: PATTAYA (Dow Jones)--PTT PCL (PTT.TH), Thailand's largest oil and gas conglomerate, expects to merge its units Aromatics (Thailand) PCL (ATC.TH) and Rayong Refinery PCL (RRC.TH) into a new entity by early 2008, said PTT President Prasert Bunsumpun.   The move is part of PTT's realignment to strengthen the competitiveness of its refinery business.   The merger plan will be proposed to shareholders of the two units for approval. Once they give the green light, the merger process is expected be completed around late 2007 or early 2008, Prasert said late Friday.   The move will harness synergies between the two companies and help cut production costs, he added.   At present, PTT owns 49.84% of Aromatics and 48.75% of Rayong Refinery.   Prasert said PTT will further merge the new entity with its 49.50%-owned refinery flagship Thai Oil PCL (TOP.TH) next year. The merger would create a new company with a total market capitalization of over THB200 billion.   "A larger-sized company would have a better potential to expand business and grow further," Prasert said.   Thai Oil is expanding its refinery capacity by 50,000 barrels per day to 275,000 barrels per day by end-2007, while Rayong Refinery operates a refinery with a capacity of 145,000 barrels per day.   Aromatics produces 530,000 tons of paraxylene a year and 300,000 tons of benzene a year.     -By Supunnabul Suwannakij, Dow Jones Newswires; 66 2266 0744; tu.suwannakij@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 30, 2007 04:50 ET (08:50 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
